chapter.verse: Al wisdom is of the Lord God, and was euere with hym, and is bifore the world.
Who noumbride the grauel of the see, and the dropis of reyn, and the daies of the world? Who mesuride the hiynesse of heuene, and the breed of erthe, and the depthe of the see?
Who enserchide the wisdom of God, that goith bifore alle thingis?
Wisdom was formed firste of alle thingis, and the vndurstonding of prudence, fro the world.
The welle of wisdom is the sone of God in hiy thingis; and the entryng of that wisdom is euerlastynge comaundementis.
To whom was the roote of wisdom schewid? and who knewe the sutilites therof?
To whom was the lore of wisdom shewid, and maad opyn? and who vndurstood the multipliyng of the entryng therof?
Oon is the hiyeste creatour of alle thingis, almyyti, and a myyti kyng, and worthi to be dred ful miche, sittynge on the trone of that wisdom, and God hauynge lordschipe.
He fourmyde `that wisdom in the Hooli Ghost, and he siy, and noumbride, and he mesuride.
And he schedde out it on alle hise werkis, and on ech fleisch bi his yifte; he yyueth it to hem that louen hym.
The drede of the Lord is glorie, and gloriyng, and gladnesse, and a coroun of ful out ioiyng.
The drede of the Lord schal delite the herte; and schal yyue gladnesse and ioie in to lengthe of daies.
To hym that dredith God, it schal be wel in the laste thingis; and he schal be blessid in the dai of his deth.
Forsothe thei to whiche wisdom apperith in siyt, louen it in siyt, and in knowyng of hise grete thingis.
The loue of God is onourable wisdom.
The bigynnyng of wisdom is the drede of the Lord; and it is formyd togidere in the wombe with feithful men, and it goith with chosun wymmen, and is knowun with iust men and feithful.
The drede of the Lord is religiouste of kunnyng.
Religiouste schal kepe, and schal iustifie the herte; and schal yyue myrthe and ioie.
It schal be wel to hym that dredith God; and he schal be blessid in the daies of his coumfort.
The fulnesse of wisdom is for to drede God; and fulnesse is of the fruytis therof.
It schal fille ech yifte of hym of generaciouns, and reseitis of the tresouris therof.
The coroun of wisdom is the drede of the Lord, and fillith pees, and the fruyt of heelthe.
And he siy, and noumbride it; forsothe euer eithir ben the yiftis of God.
Wisdom schal departe the kunnyng and vndurstondyng of prudence; and it enhaunsith the glorie of hem, that holden it.
The roote of wisdom is for to drede God; forsothe the braunchis therof ben longe durynge.
Vndurstonding, and religiouste of kunnyng ben in the tresouris of wisdom; but wisdom is abhomynacioun to synners.
The drede of the Lord puttith awei synne,
for he that is with out drede, mai not be iustified; for whi the wrathfulnesse of his pride is the destriyng of hym.
A pacient man schal suffre til in to tyme; and aftirward schal be yelding of mirthe.
Good wit schal hide the wordis of hym til in to a tyme; and the lippis of many men schulen telle out the wit of hym.
In the tresouris of wisdom is signefiyng of kunnyng;
but the worschipyng of God is abhomynacioun to a synnere.
A! sone, coueitynge wisdom, kepe thou riytfulnesse, and God schal yyue it to thee.
For whi the drede of the Lord is wisdom, and kunnyng, and that
that is wel plesaunt to hym is feith and myldenesse; and God schal fille the tressours of hym.
Be thou not rebel, and vnbileueful to the drede of the Lord; and neiye thou not to hym in double herte.
Be thou not an ypocrite in the siyt of men; and be thou not sclaundrid in thi lippis.
Take thou kepe to tho, lest thou falle, and brynge disonour to thi soule; and lest God schewe thi priuytees,
and hurtle thee doun in the myddis of the synagoge;
for thou neiyidist wickidli to the Lord, and thin herte was ful of gile and of falsnesse.
Sone, neiyynge to the seruyce of God, stonde thou in riytfulnesse, and drede; and make redi thi soule to temptacioun.
Bere doun thin herte, and suffre, and bowe doun thin eere, and take the wordis of vndirstonding, and haaste thou not in to the tyme of deeth.
Suffre thou the susteynyngis of God; be thou ioyned to God, and abide thou, that thi lijf wexe in the last tyme.
Take thou alle thing that is set to thee, and suffre thou in sorewe, and haue thou pacience in thi lownesse.
For whi gold and siluer is preued in fier; forsothe men worthi to be resseyued ben preued in the chymeney of lownesse.
Bileue thou to God, and he schal rekeuere thee; and dresse thou thi weie, and hope thou in to hym. Kepe thou his drede, and wexe thou eld ther ynne.
Ye that dreden the Lord, abide his merci, and boowe ye not awei fro hym, lest ye falle doun.
Ye that dreden the Lord, bileue to hym, and youre mede schal not be auoidid.
Ye that dreden the Lord, hope into hym, and merci schal come to you into delityng.
Ye that dreden the Lord, loue hym, and youre hertis schulen be liytned.
Sones, biholde ye the naciouns of men, and wite ye, that no man hopide in the Lord, and was schent;
noon dwellide in hise heestis, and was forsakun; ether who inwardli clepide hym, and he despiside hym `that clepide?
For whi God is pitouse, and merciful, and he schal foryyue synnes in the dai of tribulacioun; and he is defendere to alle men, that seken hym in treuthe.
Woo to the `man with double herte, and with cursid lippis, and misdoynge hondys; and to a synnere entrynge in to the lond bi twei weies.
Wo to hem that ben dissolute of herte, that bileuen not to God; and therfor thei schulen not be defendid of him.
Wo to hem that han lost pacience, and that han forsake riytful weies, and han turned awei in to schrewid weies.
And what schulen thei do, whanne the Lord schal bigynne to biholde?
Thei that dreden the Lord, schulen not be vnbileueful to his word; and thei that louen hym, schulen kepe his weie.
Thei that dreden the Lord, schulen enquere tho thingis, that ben wel plesaunt to hym; and thei that louen him, schulen be fillid with his lawe.
Thei that dreden the Lord, schulen make redi her hertis, and schulen halewe her soulis in his siyt.
Thei that dreden the Lord, schulen kepe hise comaundementis, and schulen haue pacience til to the biholdyng of hym;
and schulen seie, If we doon not penaunce, we schulen falle in to the hondis of the Lord, and not in to the hondis of men.
For bi the greetnesse of hym, so and his merci is with hym.
The sones of wisdom ben the chirche of iust men, and the nacioun of hem is obedience and loue.
Dereworthe sones, here ye the doom of the fadir; and do ye so, that ye be saaf.
For whi God onouride the fadir in sones, and he sekith, and hath maad stidfast the doom of the modir in to sones.
He that loueth God, schal preie for synnes, and he schal absteyne hym silf fro tho, and he schal be herd in the preier of daies.
And as he that tresourith, so and he that onourith his modir.
He that onourith his fadir, schal be maad myrie in sones, and he schal be herd in the dai of his preier.
He that onourith his fadir, schal lyue bi lengere lijf; and he that obeieth to the fader, schal refreische the modir.
He that dredith the Lord, onourith fadir and modir; and he schal serue in werk, and word,
and al pacience to hem that gendriden hym as to lordis.
Onoure thi fadir, that the blessyng of God come to thee; and his blessing dwellith in the laste.
The blessyng of the fadir makith stidfast the housis of sones; but the cursyng of the modir drawith out the foundementis.
Haue thou not glorie in the dispisyng of thi fadir; for it is not glorie to thee, but confusioun.
For whi the glorie of a man is of the onour of his fadir; and the schenschip of the sone is a fadir with out onour.
Sone, resseyue the elde of thi fadir, and make thou not hym sori in his lijf;
and if he failith in wit, yyue thou foryyuenesse, and dispise thou not hym in thi vertu; for whi the almes of the fadir schal not be foryetyng.
For whi good schal be restorid to thee for the synne of the modir,
and bildyng schal be maad to thee in riytfulnesse; and it schal remembre of thee in dai of tribulacioun, and thi synnes schulen be releessid, as iys in clerenesse of the sunne.
He is of ful yuel fame, that forsakith the fadir; and he that wraththith the modir, is cursid of God.
Sone, performe thi werkis in myldenesse, and thou schalt be loued ouer the glorie of men.
In as myche as thou art greet, make thee meke in alle thingis, and thou schalt fynde grace bifore God; for whi the power of God aloon is greet,
and he is onourid of meke men.

Seke thou not hiyere thingis than thou, and enquere thou not strongere thingis than thou; but euere thenke thou tho thingis, whiche God comaundide to thee; and be thou not curiouse in ful many werkis of hym.
For it is not nedeful to thee to se with thin iyen tho thingis, that ben hid.
In superflu thingis nyle thou seke manyfold; and be thou not curiouse in many werkis of hym;
for whi ful many thingis aboue the wit of men ben schewid to thee.
For the suspecioun of many men hath disseyued hem, and withhelde her wittis in vanytee.
And hard herte schal haue yuel in the laste tyme; and he that loueth perel, schal perische ther ynne.
An herte that entrith bi tweie weies, schal not haue prosperitees, ether reste; and a man of schrewid herte schal be sclaundrid in tho.
A wickid herte schal be greuyd in sorewis; and a synnere schal `hepe to do synne.
Helthe schal not be to the synagoge of proude men; for whi the thicke wode of synne schal be drawun out bi the roote in hem, and it schal not be vndurstondun.
The herte of a wise man is vndurstondun in wisdom, and a good eere schal here wisdom with al coueitise.
A wijs herte and able to vndurstonde schal absteyne it silf fro synnes, and schal haue prosperitees in the werkis of riytfulnesse.
Watir quenchith fier brennynge, and almes ayenstondith synnes.
And God, the biholdere of hym that yeldith grace, hath mynde aftirward; and he schal fynde stidefastnesse in the tyme of his fal.
Sone, defraude thou not the almes of a pore man, and turne not ouere thin iyen fro a pore man.
Dispise thou not an hungri man, and wraththe thou not a pore man in his nedynesse.
Turmente thou not the herte of a nedi man, and tarie thou not the yifte to a man that is set in angwisch.
Caste thou not awei the preiyng of a man set in tribulacioun, and turne not awei thi face fro a nedi man.
Turne not awei thi iyen fro a pore man for ire, and yyue not occasioun to men axynge to curse thee byhynde.
For the preyer of hym that cursith thee in the bitternesse of soule, schal be herd; forsothe he that made hym, schal here hym.
Make thee eesi to speke to the congregacioun of pore men, and make meke thi soule to a preest, and make meke thin heed to a greet man.
Boowe doun with out sorewe thin eere to a pore man, and yelde thi debt, and answere thou pesibli in myldenesse.
Delyuere thou hym that suffrith wrong fro the hond of a proude man, and bere thou not heuyli in thi soule.
In demynge be thou merciful as a fadir to fadirles children, and be thou for an hosebonde to the modir of hem;
and thou schalt be as an obedient sone of the hiyeste, and he schal haue merci on thee more than a modir `hath merci on hir child.
Wisdom enspirith lijf to hise sones, and resseyueth men sekinge hym, and schal go bifore in the wei of riytfulnesse; and he that loueth that wisdom,
loueth lijf, and thei that waken to it, schulen biclipe the pesiblenesse, ether swetnesse, therof.
Thei that holden it, schulen enherite lijf; and whidir it schal entre, God schal blesse.
Thei that seruen it, schulen be obeiynge to the hooli; and God loueth hem, that louen it.
He that herith it, demeth folkis; and he that biholdith it, schal dwelle tristili.
If a man bileueth to it, he schal dwelle, and enherite it; and the creaturis of hem schulen be in confermyng.
For in temptacioun it goith with hym, and among the firste it chesith hym.
It schal brynge in on hym drede, and feer, and preuyng, and it schal turmente hym in the tribulacioun of his doctryn, til it tempte hym in hise thouytis, and bileue to his soule.
And it schal make hym stidefast, and schal brynge riyt weie to hym, and it schal make hym glad;
and schal make nakid hise priuytees to hym, and schal tresore on hym kunnyng, and vndurstondyng of riytfulnesse.
Forsothe if he errith, God schal forsake hym, and schal bitake hym in to the hondis of his enemy.
Sone, kepe thou tyme, and eschewe thou fro yuel.
Be thou not aschamed for thi lijf to seie treuthe; for whi ther is schame that bryngith synne,
and ther is schame that bryngith glorie and grace.
Take thou not a face ayens thi face, nethir a leesyng ayens thi soule.
Schame thou not thi neiybore in his fal,
nether withholde thou a word in the tyme of helthe. Hide not thi wisdom in the fairnesse therof;
for whi wisdom is knowun in tunge, and wit, and kunnyng, and techyng in the word of a wijs man; and stidfastnesse is in the werkis of riytfulnesse.
Ayenseie thou not the word of treuthe in ony maner; and be thou aschamed of the leesyng of thi mislernyng.
Be thou not aschamed to knouleche thi synnes; and make thee not suget to ech man for synne.
Nyle thou stonde ayens the face of the myyti, nethir enforse thou ayens the strok of the flood.
For riytfulnesse fiyte thou for thi soule, and til to the deth stryue thou for riytfulnesse; and God schal ouercome thin enemyes for thee.
Nyle thou be swift in thi tunge, and vnprofitable and slak in thi werkis.
Nyle thou be as a lioun in thin hous, turnynge vpsedoun thi meneals, and oppressynge hem that ben sugetis to thee.
Thin hond be not redi to take, and closid togidere to yyue.
Nile thou take heed to wickid possessiouns, and seie thou not, Sufficient lijf is to me; for it schal no thing profite in the tyme of veniaunce, and of failynge, ether deth.
Sue thou not the coueitise of thin herte in thi strengthe,
and seie thou not, As Y myyte, ether who schal make me suget for my dedis? For whi God vengynge schal venge.
Seie thou not, Y haue synned, and what sorewful thing bifelle to me? For the hiyeste is a pacient yeldere.
Of the foryyuenesse of synnes, nyle thou be without drede, nether heepe thou synne on synne.
And seie thou not, The merciful doyng of God is greet; he schal haue merci on the multitude of my synnes.
For whi merci and ire neiyeth soone fro hym, and his ire biholdith on synneris.
Tarie thou not to be conuertid to the Lord, and dilaie thou not fro dai in to dai.
For whi his ire schal come sodeynli, and he schal leese thee in the time of veniaunce.
Nyle thou be angwischid in vniust richessis; for tho schulen not profite in the dai of failing, ether of deth, and of veniaunce.
Wyndewe thee not in to ech wynd, and go thou not in to ech weie; for so a synnere is preued in double tunge.
Be thou stidfast in the weie of the Lord, and in treuthe and kunnyng of thi wit; and the word of pees and riytfulnesse sue thee perfitli.
Be thou mylde to here the word of God, that thou vndurstonde, and with wisdom brynge thou forth a trewe answere.
If thou hast vndirstondyng, answere thi neiybore; ellis thin hond be on thi mouth, lest thou be takun in a word vnwiseli tauyt, and be aschamed.
Onour and glorie is in the word of a wijs man; but the tunge of an vnprudent man is his distriyng.
Be thou not clepid a preuy yuel spekere in thi lijf, and be thou not takun in thi tunge, and be aschamed.
Schame and penaunce is on a theef, and worst schenschip is on a man of double tunge. Forsothe hatrede and enemytee and dispisyng is to a preuy bacbitere.
Iustifie thou a litil man and a greet man in lijk maner.
Nile thou for a freend be maad enemye to the neiybore; for whi an yuele man schal enherite vpbreidyng and dispisyng, and ech synnere enuyouse and double tungid.
Enhaunse thee not in the thouyt of thi soule, as a bole doith; lest thi vertu be hurtlid doun bi foli,
and it ete thi leeues, and leese thi fruytis, and thou be left as a drye tree in deseert.
Forsothe a wickid soule schal leese hym that hath it, and it yyueth hym in to the ioie of the enemye, and it schal leede forth in to the part of wickid men.
A swete word multiplieth frendis, and swagith enemyes; and a tunge wel graciouse schal be plenteuouse in a good man.
Many pesible men be to thee, and oon of a thousynde be a counselour to thee.
If thou hast a frend, haue hym in temptacioun, and bitake not liytli thi silf to hym.
For ther is a frend bi his time, and he schal not dwelle in the dai of tribulacioun.
And ther is a frend which is turned to enemytee; and ther is a freend, that schal schewe opynli hatrede, and chiding, and dispisyngis.
Forsothe ther is a frend, felowe of table, and dwellith not in the dai of nede.
If a frend dwellith stidfast, he schal be as a man euene with thee, and he schal do tristili in thi meyneal thingis.
If he mekith hym silf bifore thee, and hidith hym fro thi face, thou schalt haue good frendschip of oon acord.
Be thou departid fro thin enemyes, and take heede of thi frendis.
A feithful frend is a strong defendyng; forsothe he that fyndith him, fyndith tresour.
No comparisoun is to a feithful frend; weiyng of gold and of siluer is not worthi ayens the goodnesse of his feithfulnesse.
A feithful frend is medicyn of lijf, and of vndeedlynesse; and thei that dreden the Lord, schulen fynde hym.
He that dredith the Lord, schal haue euenli good frendschip; for whi his frend schal be at the licnesse of hym.
Sone, fro thi yongthe take thou doctryn, and til to hoor heeris thou schalt fynde wisdom.
As he that erith, and that sowith, neiye thou to it, and abide thou the goode fruytis therof.
For thou schalt trauele a litil in the werk therof, and thou schalt ete soone of the generaciouns therof.
Wisdom is ouer scharp to vntauyt men, and an hertles man schal not dwelle there ynne.
As the vertu of a stoon, preuyng schal be in hem; and thei schulen not tarie to caste awei it.
Forsothe the wisdom of techyng is bi the name therof, and it is not opyn to many men; but it dwellith with hem, of whiche it is knowun, til to the siyt of God.
Sone, here thou, and take the counsel of vndurstondyng, and caste thou not awei my counsel.
Set in thi foot in to the stockis therof, and thi necke in to the bies therof.
Make suget thi schuldir, and bere it, and be thou not anoied in the boondis therof.
In al thi wille go to it, and in al thi vertu kepe the weies therof.
Enquere thou it, and it schal be maad opyn to thee; and thou made holdinge wisdom forsake not it.
For in the laste thingis thou schalt fynde reste ther ynne, and it schal turne to thee in to deliting.
And the stockis therof schulen be to thee in defence of strengthe, and the foundementis of vertu, and the bie therof in a stoole of glorie.
For whi the fairnesse of lijf is in wisdom, and the boondis therof ben heelful byndyng.
Thou schalt `were it as a stoole of glorie, and thou schalt sette on thee a coroun of thankyng.
Sone, if thou takist heede to me, thou schalt lerne wisdom; and if thou yyuest thi wille, thou schalt be wijs.
If thou bowist doun thin eere, thou schalt take teching; and if thou louest for to here, thou schalt be wijs.
Stonde thou in the multitude of prudent preestis, and be thou ioyned of herte to the wisdom of hem; that thou maist here ech telling of God, and the prouerbis of preisyng fle not awey fro thee.
And if thou seest a wijs man, wake thou to hym, and thi foot trede on the greeces of his doris.
Haue thou thouyt in the comaundementis of God, and be thou most bisi in his heestis; and he schal yyue to thee herte, and coueitise of wisdom schal be youun to thee.
Nile thou do yuels, and tho schulen not take thee.
Departe thou fro wickidnesse, and yuels schulen faile fro thee.
Sowe thou not yuels in the forewis of vnriytfulnesse, and thou schalt not repe tho in seuene fold.
Nyle thou seke of a man ledyng, nethir of a kyng the chaier of onour.
Iustifie thou not thee bifore God, for he is the knowere of the herte; and nyle thou wilne to be seyn wijs anentis the king.
Nile thou seke to be maad a iuge, no but thou maist breke wickidnessis bi vertu; lest thou drede the face of a myyti man, and sette sclaundre in thi swiftnesse.
Do thou not synne in the multitude of a cytee, nether sende thee in to the puple;
nether bynde thou double synnes, for thou schalt not be giltles in oon.
Nyle thou be a coward in thi soule, to preie;
and dispise thou not to do almes.
Seie thou not, God schal biholde in the multitude of my yiftis; and whanne Y schal offre to God alther hiyeste, he schal take my yiftis.
Scorne thou not a man in the bitternesse of soule; for whi God is the biholdere, that makith meke, and enhaunsith.
Nyle thou loue a leesyng ayens thi brother; nether do thou in lijk maner ayens a frend.
Nyle thou wilne to lie ony leesing; for whi the contynuaunce therof is not good.
Nyle thou be a ianglere in the multitude of preestis; and reherse thou not a word in thi preier.
Haate thou not trauelouse werkis, and erthetilthe maad of the hiyeste.
Arette thou not thee in the multitude of vnlernyd men.
Haue thou mynde on ire, for it schal not tarie.
Make thou meke greetli thi spirit, for whi the veniaunce of the fleisch of an vnpitouse man is fier, and worm.
Nyle thou trespasse ayens thi frend dilaiynge monei; nether dispise thou a ful dereworth brother for gold.
Nyle thou departe fro a wijs womman, and good, whom thou hast gete in the drede of the Lord; for whi the grace of hir schamefastnesse is aboue gold.
Hirte thou not a seruaunt worchynge in treuthe, nether an hirid man yyuynge his lijf.
A witti seruaunt be dereworthe to thee as thi soule; defraude thou not hym of fredom, nether forsake thou hym nedi.
Beestis ben to thee? take thou heede to tho; and if tho ben profitable, dwelle tho stille at thee.
Sones ben to thee? teche thou hem, and bowe thou hem fro her childheed.
Douytris ben to thee? kepe thou the bodi of hem, and schewe thou not glad face to hem.
Yyue thi douyter to mariage, and thou doist a greet werk; and yyue thou hir to a wijs man.
If a womman is to thee aftir thi soule, caste hir not awei; and bitake thou not thee in alle thin herte to an hateful womman.
Onoure thi fadir; and foryete thou not the weilyngis of thi modir.
Haue thou mynde that thou haddist not be, no but bi hem, and yelde thou to hem as and thei diden to thee.
In al thi soule drede thou God, and halewe thou hise preestis.
In al thi vertu loue thou him that made thee; and forsake thou not hise mynystris.
Onoure thou God of al thi soule; and onoure thou preestis, and clense thee with armes.
Yyue thou to hem the part of the firste fruytis, and of purgyng, as also it is comaundid to thee; and of thi negligence purge thou thee with fewe men.
Thou schalt offre to the Lord the yyfte of thin armes, and the sacrifice of halewyng, the bigynnyngis of hooli men.
And dresse thin hond to a pore man, that thi merci and blessyng be performyd.
Grace is youun in the siyt of ech that lyueth; and forbede thou not grace to a deed man.
Faile thou not in coumfort to hem that wepen; and go thou with hem that morenen.
Be thou not slow to visite a sijk man; for bi these thingis thou schalt be maad stidfast in loue.
In alle thi werkis haue thou mynde on thi laste thingis; and thou schalt not do synne withouten ende.
Chide thou not with a miyti man, leste thou falle in to hise hondis.
Stryue thou not with a riche man, lest perauenture he make ple ayenward to thee.
For whi gold and siluer hath lost many men; and it stretchith forth til to the herte of kyngis, and turneth.
Chide thou not with a man, a ianglere, and leie thou not trees in to his fier.
Comyne thou not with an vntauyt man, lest he speke yuele of thi kynrede.
Dispise thou not a man turnynge awei hym silf fro synne, nether vpbreide thou hym; haue thou mynde, that alle we ben in corrupcioun.
Dispise thou not a man in his eelde; for whi of vs men wexen eld.
Nyle thou make ioye of thin enemy deed, witynge that alle we dien, and wolen not come in to ioie of oure enemys.
Dispise thou not the tellyng of wise preestes, and be thou conuersaunt in the prouerbis of hem;
for of hem thou schalt lerne wisdom, and techyng of vndurstondyng, and to serue without pleynt to grete men.
The tellyng of eldere men passe not thee; for thei han lerned of her fadris.
For of hem thou schalt lerne vndurstondyng; and in the tyme of nede thou schalt yyue answere.
Kyndle thou not the coolis of synneris, and repreue hem; and be thou not brent with the flawme of fier of her synnes.
Stonde thou not ayens the face of a man ful of dispisyng; lest he sitte as a spiere to thi mouth.
Nyle thou leene to a man strongere than thou; that if thou hast lent, haue thou it as lost.
Biheete thou not aboue thi power; that if thou hast bihiyt, bithenke thou as yeldynge.
Deme thou not ayens a iuge; for he demeth vp that, that is iust.
Go thou not in the weie with an hardi man, lest perauenture he agregge hise yuels in thee; for he goith aftir his wille, and thou schalt perische togidere with his foli.
Make thou not chidyng with a wrathful man, and go thou not in to desert with an hardi man; for whi blood is as nouyt bifore hym, and where noon help is, he schal hurtle thee doun.
Haue thou not councel with foolis; for thei moun not loue, no but tho thingis that plesen hem.
Make thou not a counsel bifore a straunger; for thou noost, what he schal bringe forth. Make not thin herte knowun to ech man; lest perauenture he brynge to thee fals grace, and dispise thee.
Loue thou not gelousli the womman of thi bosum; lest sche schewe on thee the malice of yuel doctryn.
Yyue thou not to a womman the power of thi soule; lest sche entre in thi vertu, and thou be schent.
Biholde thou not a womman of many willis; lest perauenture thou falle in to the snaris of hir.
Be thou not customable with a daunseresse, nethir here thou hir; lest perauenture thou perische in the spedi werk of hir.
Biholde thou not a virgyn; lest perauenture thou be sclaundrid in the feirnesse of hir.
Yyue not thi soule to hooris in ony thing; lest thou leese thee, and thi soule, and thin eritage.
Nyle thou biholde aboute in the lanys of the cytee; nethir erre thou in the large streetis therof.
Turne awei thi face fro a womman `wel arayed; and biholde thou not aboute the fairnesse of othere.
Many men han perischid for the fairnesse of a womman; and `herbi couetise brenneth `an hiy as fier.
Ech womman which is an hoore, ethir customable to fornycacioun, schal be defoulid as a fen in the weie.
Many men wondrynge on the fairnesse of an alien womman weren maad repreuable, for whi the speche of hir brenneth an hiy as fier.
Sitte thou not in ony maner with an alien womman, nether reste thou with hir on a bed;
and iangle thou not with hir in wyn, lest perauenture thin herte boowe in to hir, and thou falle in to perdicioun bi thi blood.
Forsake thou not an eld frend; for a newe frend schal not be lijk hym.
Newe wijn is a newe frend; it schal wexe eld, and thou schalt drinke it with swetnesse.
Coueyte thou not the glorie and richessis of a synnere; for thou noost, what distriyng of hym schal come.
The wrong of vniust men plese not thee, and wite thou that a wickid man schal not plese til to hellis.
Be thou fer fro a man that hath power to sle, and thou schalt not haue suspicioun of the drede of deth;
and if thou neiyest to hym, nyle thou do ony trespasse, lest perauenture he take awei thi lijf.
Knowe thou the comynyng of deth; for thou schalt entre in to the myddis of snaris, and thou schalt go on the armuris of hem that sorewen.
Bi thi vertu kepe thee fro thi neiybore; and trete thou with wise men and prudent men.
Just men be gestis, ethir mete feris, to thee; and gloriyng be `to thee in the dreed of God.
And the thouyt of God be to thee in wit; and al thi tellynge be in the heestis of the hiyeste.
Werkis schulen be preisid in the hond of crafti men, and the prince of the puple in the wisdom of his word; forsothe in the wit of eldere men a word.
A man, a ianglere, is dredeful in his citee; and a fool hardi man in his word schal be hateful.
A wijs iuge schal deme his puple; and the prinshed of a witti man schal be stidfast.
Aftir the iuge of the puple, so and hise mynystris; and what maner man is the gouernour of the citee, siche ben also men dwellinge ther ynne.
An vnwijs king schal leese his puple; and citees schulen be enhabitid bi the wit of prudent men.
The power of erthe is in the hond of God, and al the wickidnesse of hethene men is abhomynable; and he schal reise a profitable gouernour at a tyme on it.
The power of man is in the hond of God; and he schal sette his onour on the face of a wijs man in the lawe.
Haue thou not mynde on al the wrong of the neiybore; and do thou no thing in the werkis of wrong.
Pride is hateful bifore God and men; and al the wickidnesse of hethene men is abhomynable.
A rewme is translatid fro a folk in to folk, for vnriytfulnessis, and wrongis, and dispisyngis, and dyuerse gilis.
No thing is cursidere than an auerouse man. What art thou proude, thou erthe and aische?
No thing is worse, than for to loue monei; for whi this man hath also his soule set to sale, for in his lijf he hath cast awei hise ynneste thingis.
Ech power is schort lijf; lengere siknesse greueth the leche.
A leche kittith awei schort siknesse; so and a king is to dai, and to morewe he schal die.
Forsothe whanne a man schal die, he schal enherite serpentis, and beestis, and wormes.
The bigynnyng of pride of man was to be apostata fro God;
for his herte yede awei fro hym that made hym. For whi pride is the bigynnyng of al synne; he that holdith it, schal be fillid with cursyngis, and it schal distrye hym in to the ende.
Therfor the Lord hath schent the couentis of yuele men, and hath destried hem til `in to the ende.
God destriede the seetis of proude duykis; and made mylde men to sitte for hem.
God made drie the rootis of proude folkis; and plauntide meke men of tho folkis.
The Lord destriede the londis of folkis; and loste tho `til to the foundement.
He made drie the rootis of hem, and loste hem; and made the mynde of hem to ceesse fro the erthe.
God loste the mynde of proude men; and lefte the mynde of meke men in wit.
Pride was not maad to men; nether wrathfulnesse to the nacioun of wymmen.
This seed of men that dredith God, schal be onourid; but this seed schal be disonourid, that passith the comaundementis of the Lord.
In the myddis of britheren the gouernour of hem is in onour; and thei that dreden God, schulen be in hise iyen.
The glorie of riche men onourid and of pore men is the drede of God.
Nyle thou dispise a iust pore man; and nyle thou magnefie a riche synful man.
The iuge is greet, and is miyti in onour; and he is not grettere than that man that dredith God.
Fre children seruen a witti seruaunt; and a prudent man and lerned schal not grutche, whanne he is blamed, and an vnkunnynge man schal not be onourid.
Nyle thou enhaunse thee in thi werk to be don; and nyle thou be slow in the tyme of angwisch.
He is betere that worchith, and hath plente in alle thingis, than he that hath glorie, and nedith breed.
Sone, kepe thi soule in myldenesse; and yyue thou onour to it, aftir his merit.
Who schal iustifie hym that synneth ayens his soule? and who schal onoure hym that disonourith his soule?
A pore man hath glorie bi his lernyng and drede; and ther is a man that is onourid for his catel.
Forsothe if a man hath glorie in pouert, hou myche more in catel? and he that hath glorie in catel, drede pouerte.
The wisdom of a man maad meke schal enhaunse his heed; and schal make hym to sitte in the middis of grete men.
Preise thou not a man in his fairnesse; nether dispise thou a man in his siyt.
A bee is litil among briddis; and his fruyt hath the bigynnyng of swetnesse.
Haue thou neuere glorie in clothing, and be thou not enhaunsid in the dai of thin onour; for whi the werkis of the hiyeste aloon ben wondurful, and hise werkis ben gloriouse, and hid, and vnseyn.
Many tyrauntis han sete in trone; and a man of whom was no supposyng bar the diademe.
Many myyty men ben oppressid strongli; and gloriouse men ben youun in to the hondis of othere men.
Bifore that thou axe, blame thou not ony man; and whanne thou hast axid, blame thou iustli.
Bifor that thou here, answere thou not a word; and in the myddis of eldere men adde thou not to speke.
Stryue thou not, of that thing that disesith not thee; and stonde thou not in the dom of synnes.
Sone, thi dedis be not in many thingis; and if thou art riche, thou schalt not be with out part of gilt. For if thou suest, thou schalt not take; and thou schalt not ascape, if thou rennist bifore.
Ther is a man trauelynge, and hastynge, and sorewynge, and vnpitouse; and bi so myche more he schal not haue plentee.
Ther is a man fade, nedi of rekyueryng, failynge more in vertu, and plenteuouse in pouert;
and the iye of God bihelde hym in good, and reiside hym fro his lownesse, and enhaunsid his heed; and many men wondriden in him, and onouriden God.
Goodis and yuels, lijf and deth, pouert and oneste, ben of God.
Wisdom, and lernyng, and kunnyng of the lawe ben anentis the Lord; loue and the weies of goode men ben at him.
Errour and derknessis ben maad togidere to synneris; forsothe thei that maken ful out ioye in yuel, wexen eld togidere in to yuels.
The yifte of God dwellith to iust men; and encreessyngis of hym schulen haue prosperitees without ende.
A man is that is maad riche in doynge scarsli, and this is the part of his mede,
in that that he seith, Y haue founden reste to me, and now Y aloone schal ete of my goodis.
And he noot that tyme passith hym, and deth neiyeth, and he schal leeue alle thingis to othere men, and schal die.
Stonde thou in thi testament, and speke thou togidere in it; and wexe thou eld in the werk of thin heestis.
Dwelle thou not in the werkis of synneris; but triste thou in God, and dwelle in thi place.
For it is esy in the iyen of God, sudeynli to make onest a pore man.
The blessing of God haastith in to the meede of a iust man; and the going forth of hym makith fruyt in swift onour.
Seie thou not, What is nede to me? and what goodis schulen be me her aftir?
Seie thou not, Y am sufficient, and what schal Y be maad worse heraftir?
In the dai of goodis be thou not vnmyndeful of yuels, and in the dai of yuels be thou not vnmyndeful of goodis;
for it is esi bifor God to yelde in the dai of deth to ech man aftir hise weies.
The malice of oon our makith foryeting of moost letcherie; and in the ende of a man is makyng nakid of hise werkis.
Preise thou not ony man bifore his deth; for whi a man is knowun in hise sones.
Brynge thou not ech man in to thin hous; for whi many tresouns ben of a gileful man.

For whi as the entrailis of stynkynge thingis breken out, and as a partrich is led in to a trap, ether net, and as a capret is led in to a snare, so and the herte of proude men; and as a biholdere seynge the fal of his neiybore.
For he turneth goodis in to yuels, and settith tresouns, and puttith a wem on chosun men.
Fier is encreessid of a sparcle, and blood is encreessid of a gileful man; for whi a synful man settith tresoun to blood.
Take heede to thee fro a gileful man, for he makith yuels; lest perauenture he bringe yn on thee scornyng with outen ende.
Resseyue thou an alien to thee, and he schal distrie thee in whirlwynd, and he schal make thee alien fro thin owne weies.
If thou doist wel, wite thou to whom thou doist; and miche grace schal be to thi goodis.
Do thou wel to a iust man, and thou schalt fynde greet yelding; thouy not of hym, certis of the Lord.
It is not wel to hym that is customable in yuels, and to hym that yyueth not almes; for whi the hiyeste bothe hatith synneris, and doith merci to hem that doen penaunce.
Yyue thou to a merciful man, and resseyue thou not a synnere; God schal yelde veniaunce bothe to vnfeithful men and to synneris, kepynge hem in the dai of veniaunce.
Yyue thou to a good man, and resseyue thou not a synnere.
Do thou good to a meke man, and yyue thou not to an vnpitouse man; forbede thou to yyue looues to hym, lest in tho he be myytiere than thou.
For thou schalt fynde double yuels in alle goodis, whiche euere thou doist to hym; for whi the hiyeste bothe hatith synneris, and schal yelde veniaunce to vnfeithful men.
A frend schal not be knowun in goodis, and an enemy schal not be hid in yuels.
In the goodis of a man hise enemyes ben sori; and a frend is knowun in the sorewe and malice of him.
Bileue thou neuer to thin enemy; for his wickidnesse roustith as irun.
Thouy he be maad meke, and go lowe, caste awei thi soule, and kepe thee fro him.

Sette thou not him bisidis thee, nether sitte he at thi riytside, lest he turne and stonde in thi place; lest perauenture he turne in to thi place, and enquere thi chaier, and in the laste tyme thou know mi wordis, and be prickid in my wordis.
Who schal do medecyn to an enchauntere smytun of a serpent, and to alle men that neiyen to beestis, and to him that goith with an yuel man, and is wlappid in the synnes of him?
In oon our he schal dwelle with thee; sotheli if thou bowist awei, he schal not bere vp.
The enemy makith swete in hise lippis, and in his herte he settith tresoun to ouerturne thee in to the dich.
The enemy wepith in hise iyen; and if he fyndith tyme, he schal not be fillid of blood.
If yuels bifallen to thee, thou schalt fynde hym the formere there.
The enemy schal wepe bifore thin iyen, and he as helpynge schal vndurmyne thi feet.
He schal stire his heed, and he schal beete with hond; and he schal speke priuyli many yuels of thee, and schal chaunge his chere.
He that touchith pitch, schal be defoulid of it; and he that comyneth with a proude man, schal clothe pride.
He reisith a weiyte on hym silf, that comyneth with a more onest man than hym silf; and be thou not felowe to a man richere than thou.
What schal a cawdroun comyne to a pot? for whanne tho hirtlen hem silf togidere, the pot schal be brokun.
A riche man schal do vniustli, and schal gnaste; but a pore man hirt schal be stille.
If thou yyuest, he schal take thee; and if thou hast not, he schal forsake thee.
If thou hast, he schal lyue togidere with thee, and schal make thee voide; and he schal not haue sorewe on thee.
If thou art nedeful to hym, he schal disseyue thee; and he schal flatere, and schal yyue hope, tellinge to thee alle goodis; and schal seie, What is nede to thee?

And he schal schende thee in hise metis, til he anyntische thee twies and thries, and at the laste he schal scorne thee; aftirward he schal se, and schal forsake thee, and he schal moue his heed to thee.
Be thou maad meke to God, and abide thou hise hondis.
Take heede, lest thou be disseyued, and be maad lowe in foli.
Nyle thou be lowe in thi wisdom, lest thou be maad low, and be disseyued in to foli.
Whanne thou art clepid of a miytiere man, go thou awei; for bi this he schal more clepe thee.
Be thou not greetli pressyng, lest thou be hurtlid doun; and be thou not fer fro hym, lest thou go in to foryetyng.
Witholde thou not to speke with hym euenli, and bileue thou not to hise many wordis; for of myche speche he schal tempte thee, and he schal leiye priuyli, and schal axe thee of thin hid thingis.
His cruel soule schal kepe thi wordis, and he schal not spare of malice, and of bondis.
Be war to thee, and take heede diligentli to thin heryng; for thou goist with thi distriyng.
But thou heringe tho thingis, se as in sleep, and thou schalt wake.
In al thi lijf loue thou God, and inwardli clepe thou him in thin heelthe.
Ech beeste loueth a beeste lijk it silf; so and ech man owith to loue his neiybore.
Ech fleisch schal be ioyned to fleisch lijk it silf, and ech man schal be felouschipid to a man lijk hym silf.
As a wulf schal comyne sum tyme with a lomb, so a synnere with a iust man.
What comininge is of an hooli man to a dogge? ethir what good part is of a riche man to a pore man?
The huntyng of a lioun is a wielde asse in desert; so the lesewis of riche men ben pore men.
And as mekenesse is abhomynacioun to a proude man, so and a pore man is abhomynacioun of a riche man.
A riche man moued is confermed of hise frendis; but a meke man, whanne he fallith, schal be cast out, yhe, of knowun men.
Many rekyuereris ben to a riche man disseyued; he spak proudli, and thei iustifieden hym.
A meke man is disseiued, ferthermore also he is repreuyd; he spak wiseli, and no place was youun to hym.
The riche man spak, and alle men weren stille; and thei schulen brynge his word til to the cloudis.
A pore man spak, and thei seien, Who is this? and if he offendith, thei schulen destrye hym.
Catel is good to hym, to whom is no synne in conscience; and `the worste pouert is in the mouth of a wickid man.
The herte of a man chaungith his face, ethir in good ethir in yuel.
Of hard and with trauel thou schalt fynde the step of a good herte, and a good face.
Blessid is the man, that stood not bi the word of his mouth, and was not prickid in the sorewe of trespas.
He is blessid, that hath not sorewe of his soule, and fallith not doun fro his hope.
Catel is with out resoun to a coueitouse man, and hard nygard; and wherto is gold to an enuyouse man?
He that gaderith of his wille vniustli, gaderith to othere men; and another man schal mak wast in hise goodis.
To what othere man schal he be good, which is wickid to hym silf? and he schal not be myrye in hise goodis.
No thing is worse, than he that hath enuye to hym silf; and this is the yelding of his malice.
And if he doith good, he doith vnwityngli, and not wilfuli; and at the laste he schewith his malice.
The iye of an enuyous man is wickid, and turnynge awei the face, and dispisynge his soule.
The iye of the coueitouse man is neuere fillid; he schal not be fillid in to the part of wickidnesse, til he performe vnriytfulnesse, and make drie his soule.
An yuel iye to yuels, and the nedi man schal not be fillid of breed; and he schal be in sorewe on his table.
Sone, if thou hast, do wel with thi silf, and offre thou worthi offryngis to God.
Be thou myndeful that deth schal not tarie, and the testament of hellis, which is schewid to thee; for whi the testament of this world schal die bi deth.
Bifore deth do thou good to thi frend, and bi thi miytis stretche thou forth, and yyue to a pore man.
Be thou not disseyued of a good dai, and a litil part of a good day passe not thee.
Whether thou schalt not leeue to othere men thi sorewis, and trauels?
In the departyng of lot yyue thou, and take; and iustifie thi soule.
Bifore thi deth worche thou riytfulnesse; for at hellis it is not to fynde mete.
Ech man schal wexe eld as hey, and as a leef bryngynge fruit in a greene tree.
Othere ben gendrid, and othere ben cast doun; so the generacioun of fleisch and blood, another is endid, and another is borun.
Ech corruptible werk schal faile in the ende; and he that worchith it, schal go with it.
And al chosun werk schal be iustified; and he that worchith it, schal be onourid in it.
Blessid is the man, that schal dwelle in wisdom, and that schal bithenke in riytfulnesse, and schal thenke in wit the biholding of God.
Which thenkith out, ether fyndith out, the weies of hym in his herte, and schal be vndurstondynge in the hid thingis of hym; goynge as a serchere aftir it, and stondynge in the weies of it.
Which biholdith bi the wyndows therof, and herith in the yatis therof;
which restith nyy the hous therof, and settith a stak in the wallis therof. He schal sette his litil hous at the hondis of hym, and goodis schulen reste in his litil hous, bi duryng of the world;
he schal sette hise sones vndur the hilyng therof, and he schal dwelle vndur the boowis therof;
he schal be kyuerid vndur the hilyng therof fro heete, and he schal reste in the glorie therof.
He that dredith God, schal do goode werkis; and he that holdith riytfulnesse, schal take it.
And it as a modir onourid schal meete hym, and as a womman fro virgynyte it schal take hym.
It shal feede hym with the breed of lijf, and of vndurstonding; and it schal yyue drynke to hym with watir of heelful wisdom; it schal be maad stidfast in hym, and he schal not be bowid.
And it schal holde hym, and he schal not be schent; and it schal enhaunse hym at his neiyboris.
And in the myddis of the chirche he schal opene his mouth; and God schal fille hym with the spirit of wisdom, and of vndurstonding, and schal clothe hym with the stoole of glorie.
God schal tresore on hym myrthe, and ful out ioiyng; and schal enherite hym with euerlastynge name.
Fonned men schulen not take that wisdom, and witti men schulen meete it. Fonned men schulen not se it; for whi it goith awey fer fro pride, and gile.
Men leesyngmongeris schulen not be myndful therof, and sothefast men ben foundun ther ynne; and schulen haue prosperite `til to the biholding of God.
Preisyng is not fair in the mouth of a synnere, for he is not sent of the Lord.
For whi wisdom yede forth fro God; forsothe heriyng schal stonde nyy the wisdom of God, and it schal be plenteuouse in a feithful mouth, and the Lord schal yyue it to him.
Seie thou not, It goith awei bi God; for whi do thou not tho thingis, whiche God hatith.
Seie thou not, He made me for to erre; for whi wickid men ben not nedeful to hym.
The Lord hatith al cursidnesse of errour, and it schal not be amyable to hem, that dreden hym.
At the bigynnyng God made man, and lefte him in the hond of his councel.
He addide hise comaundementis, and lawis;
if thou wolt kepe the comaundementis, tho schulen kepe thee, and kepe plesaunt feith with outen ende.
He hath set to thee watir and fier; dresse thin hond to that, that thou wolt.
Bifor man is lijf and deth, good and yuel; that, that plesith hym, schal be youun to hym.
For whi the wisdom of God is myche, and he is strong in power, and seeth alle men without ceessing.
The iyen of the Lord ben to hem, that dreden hym; and he knowith al the trauel of man.
He comaundide not to ony man to do wickidli; and he yaf not to ony man space to do synne.
For he coueytith not the multitude of sones vnfeithful and vnprofitable.
Be thou not glad in wickid sones, if thei ben multiplied; nether delite thou on hem, if the drede of God is not in hem.
Bileue thou not to the lijf of hem, and biholde thou not in to the trauels of hem.
For whi betere is oon dredynge God, than a thousynde wickid sones.
And it is more profitable to die with out sones, than to leeue wickid sones.
A cuntrei shal be enhabitid of o witti man; and it schal be maad desert of thre wickid men.
Myn iye siy many othere thingis, and myn eere herde strongere thingis than these.
Fier schal brenne an hiy in the synagoge of synneris, and yre schal brenne an hiy in a folk vnbileuful.
Elde giauntis that weren distried, tristynge on her vertu, preieden not for her synnes;
and God sparide not the pilgrymage of hem, but he killide hem, and curside hem, for the pride of her word.
He hadde not merci on hem, and he loste al the folk enhaunsynge hem silf in her synnes.
And as he killide sixe hundrid thousynde of foot men, that weren gaderid togidere in the hardnesse of her herte; and if oon hadde be hard nollid, wondur if he hadde be giltles.
For whi merci and ire is with hym; preier is myyti, and schedynge out ire.
Bi his merci, so is the chastisyng of ech man; he is demyd bi hise werkis.
A synnere in raueyn schal not ascape; and the sufferaunce of hym that doith merci schal not tarie.
Al merci schal make place to ech man, aftir the merit of his werkis, and aftir the vndurstonding of his pilgrymage.
Seie thou not, Y schal be hid fro God; and fro the hiyeste, who schal haue mynde on me?
Seie thou not, Y schal not be knowun in a greet puple; for whi which is my soule in so greet a creature?
Lo! heuene, and the heuenes of heuenes, the greet occian, and al erthe, and tho thingis that ben in tho, schulen be mouyd in his siyt;
munteyns togidere, and litle hillis, and the foundementis of erthe; and whanne God biholdith tho, tho schulen be schakun togidere with tremblyng.
And in alle these thingis the herte is vnwijs, and ech herte is vndurstondun of hym.
And who vndurstondith hise weies? and `who vndurstondith a tempest, which the iye of man siy not?

For whi ful many werkis of hym ben `in hid thingis, but who schal telle out the werkis of his riytfulnesse, ether who schal suffre? For whi the testament is fer fro summe men; and the axyng of men is in the endyng.
He that is maad litil in herte, thenkith veyn thingis; and a man vnprudent and a fool thenkith fonned thingis.

Sone, here thou me, and lerne thou techyng of wit, and yyue thou tent to my wordis in thin herte; and Y schal seie techyng in equyte, and Y schal seke to telle out wisdom. And yyue thou tent to my wordis in thin herte;
and Y seie in equyte of spirit the vertues, whiche God hath set on hise werkis at the bigynnyng, and in treuthe Y telle out the kunnyng of him.
In the doom of God ben hise werkis fro the bigynnyng; and in the ordynaunce of tho he departyde the partis of tho, and he departide the bigynnyngis of tho in hise folkis.
He ournede with outen ende the werkis of hem; thei hungriden not, nether traueliden, and thei ceessiden not of her werkis.
Ech schal not make streit the nexte to hym, til in to with outen ende.
Be thou not vnbileueful to the word of him.
Aftir these thingis God bihelde `in to the erthe, and fillide it with hise goodis.
Forsothe the soule of ech lyuynge thing teld bifore his face; and thilke soule is eft the turnyng ayen of tho thinges.
God formede man of erthe; and aftir his ymage he made man.
And eft he turnede man in to that ymage; and aftir hym silf he clothide hym with vertu.
He yaf to hym the noumbre of daies, and tyme; and he yaf to him power of tho thingis that ben on erthe.
He settide the drede of man on al fleisch, and he was lord of beestis and fliynge briddis.
He formyde of man an help lijk hym; he yaf to hem councel, and tunge, and iyen, and eeris, and herte to thenke out; and he fillide hem with techyng of vndurstondyng.
He made to hem the kunnyng of spirit, he fillide the herte of hem with wit; and he schewide to hem yuels and goodis.
He settide the iye of hem on the hertes of hem, to schewe to hem the grete thingis of hise werkis,
that thei preise togidere the name of halewyng; and to haue glorie in hise meruels, that thei telle out the grete thingis of hise werkis.
He addide to hem techyng; and he enheritide hem with the lawe of lijf.
He ordeynyde an euerlastynge testament with hem; and he schewide to hem hise riytfulnesse, and domes.
And the iye of hem siy the grete thingis of his onour, and the eeris of hem herden the onour of vois; and he seide to hem, Take heede to you fro al wickid thing.
And he comaundide to hem, to ech man of his neiybore.
The weies of hem ben euere bifore hym; tho ben not hid fro hise iyen.
On ech folk he made souereyn a gouernour;
and Israel was maad the opyn part of God.
And alle the werkis of hem ben as the sunne in the siyt of God; and hise iyen biholden with out ceessyng in the weies of hem.
Testamentis weren not hid fro the wickidnesse of hem; and alle the wickydnessis of hem weren in the siyt of God.
The almes of a man is as a bagge with hym, and it schal kepe the grace of a man as the appil of the iye;
and afterward man schal rise ayen, and it schal yelde to hem a yelding, to ech man in to the heed of hem; and schal turne in to the lower partis of erthe.
Forsothe it yaf to men repentinge the weie of riytfulnesse, and confermede men failynge to suffre, and ordeynede to hem the part of treuthe.
Turne thou to the Lord, and forsake thi synnes;
preye thou bifore the face of the Lord, and make thou lesse hirtingis.
Turne thou ayen to the Lord, and turne thou awei fro thin vnriytfulnesse, and hate thou greetli cursyng.
And knowe thou the riytfulnessis, and domes of God; and stonde thou in the part of good purpos, and of preier of the hiyeste God.
Go thou in to the partis of the hooli world, with men lyuynge, and yyuynge knouleching to God.
Dwelle thou not in the errour of wickid men. Knouleche thou bifore deth; knouleching perischith fro a deed man, as no thing.
Lyuynge thou schalt knouleche, lyuynge and hool thou schalt knowleche, and schalt herie God; and thou schalt haue glorie in the merciful doyngis of hym.
The merci of God is ful greet, and his help to hem that conuerten to hym.
For whi not alle thingis moun be in men; for whi the sone of man is not vndeedli, and malices plesiden in to vanyte.
What is clerere than the sunne? and this schal faile; ethir what is worse than that, that fleisch and blood thouyte out? and of this he schal be repreued.
He biholdith the vertu of hiynesse of heuene; and alle men ben erthe and aische.
He that lyueth with out bigynnyng and ende, made of nouyt alle thingis togidere; God alone schal be iustified, and he dwellith a king vnouercomun with outen ende.
Who schal suffice to telle out his werkis?
for whi who schal seke the grete thingis of hym?
But who schal telle out the vertu of his greetnesse? ether who schal leie to for to telle out his mercy?
It is not to make lesse, nether to leie to; nethir it is to fynde the grete thingis of God.
Whanne a man hath endid, thanne he schal bigynne; and whanne he hath restid, he schal worche.
What is a man, and what is the glorie of him? and what is good, ether what is the wickid thing of him?
The noumbre of the daies of men, that ben comynli an hundrid yeer, ben arettid as the dropis of the watir of the see; and as the stoon of grauel, so a fewe yeeris in the dai of euerlastyngnesse.
For this thing God is pacient in hem, and schedith out on hem his merci.
He siy the presumpcioun of her herte, for it was yuel; and he knew the distriyng of hem, for it was wickid.
Therfor he fillide his merci in hem, and schewide to hem the weie of equite.
The merciful doyng of man is aboute his neiybore; but the merci of the Lord is ouer ech fleisch.
He that hath merci, and techith, and chastisith as a scheepherde his floc,
do merci, takynge the techyng of merciful doyng; and he that hastith in the domes therof.
Sone, in goodis yyue thou not pleynt, and in ech yifte yyue thou not heuynesse of an yuel word.
Whether dew schal not kele heete? so and a word is betere than yifte.
Lo! whether a word is not aboue a good yifte? but euer ethir is with a man iustified.
A fool schal vpbreide scharpli; and the yifte of an vntauyt man makith iyen to faile.
Bifore the doom make thou redi riytfulnesse to thee; and lerne thou, bifore that thou speke.
Bifore sikenesse yyue thou medicyn; and bifore the doom axe thi silf, and thou schalt fynde merci in the siyt of God.
Bifore sikenesse make the meke, and in the tyme of sikenesse schewe thi lyuyng.
Be thou not lettid to preye euere, and drede thou not to be iustified til to deth; for whi the meede of God dwellith with outen ende.
Bifore preier make redi thi soule; and nyle thou be as a man that temptith God.
Haue thou mynde of ire in the dai of endyng; and make thou in lyuyng the tyme of yelding.
Haue thou mynde of pouert in the dai of abundaunce; and the nede of pouert in the tyme of richessis.
Fro the morewtid `til to the euentid the tyme schal be chaungid; and alle these thingis ben swift in the iyen of God.
A wise man schal drede in alle thingis; and in the daies of trespassis he schal fle fro vnkunnyng, ether slouthe.
Ech fel man knowith wisdom; and to hym that fyndith it, he schal yyue knouleching.
Witti men in wordis also thei diden wiseli, and vndurstoden treuthe, and riytfulnesse; and bisouyten prouerbis and domes.
Go thou not aftir thi coueitises; and be thou turned awei fro thi wille.
If thou yyuest to thi soule the coueitisis therof, it schal make thee in to ioie to thin enemyes.
Delite thou not in cumpenyes, nether in litle cumpenyes; for whi the synnyng of hem is contynuel.
Be thou not meene in the stryuyng of looue, and sum thing is to thee in the world; for whi thou schalt be enuyouse to thi soule.
A drunkelew werk man schal not be maad riche; and he that chargith not litle synnes, fallith doun litil and litil.
Wyn and wymmen maken to be apostataas, yhe, wise men; and thei repreuen witti men.
And he that ioyneth hym silf to hooris, schal be wickid; rot and wormes schulen enherite hym, and he schal be set an hiy in to more ensaumple, and his soule schal be takun awei fro noumbre.
He that bileueth soone, is vnstable in herte, and schal be maad lesse; and he that trespassith ayens his soule, schal be had ferthermore.
He that ioieth in wickidnesse, schal be cursid; and he that hatith blamyng, schal be maad lesse in lijf; and he that hatith ianglyng, quenchith malice.
He that synneth ayens his soule, schal repente; and he that is myrie in malice, schal be cursid.
Reherse thou not an hard word, and wickid; and thou schalt not be maad lesse.
Nyle thou telle thi wit to frend and enemye; and if trespas is to thee, nyle thou make nakid.
For he schal here thee, and schal kepe thee, and he as defendynge the synne schal hate thee; and so he schal be euere with thee.
Thou hast herd a word ayens thi neiybore; die it togidere in thee, and triste thou that it schal not breke thee.
A fool trauelith greetli of the face of a word, as the sorewe of beryng of a yong child.
An arowe fastned in the hipe of a dogge, so a word in the herte of a fool.
Repreue thou a frend, lest perauenture he vndurstonde not, and seie, Y dide not; ether if he hath do, lest he adde to do eft.
Repreue thou a neiybore, lest perauenture he seie not; and if he seith, lest perauenture he reherse.
Repreue thou a frend, for whi trespassynge is don ofte;
and bileue thou not to ech word. Ther is a man that fallith bi his tunge, but not of wille.
For `whi who is he, that trespassith not in his tunge? Repreue thou a neiybore, bifore that thou manaasse;
and yyue thou place to the drede of the hiyeste. For whi al wisdom is the drede of God, and in that wisdom for to drede God; and the ordynaunce of lawe is in al wisdom.
And the teching of wickidnesse is not wisdom; and the prudence of synnes is not good thouyt.
Ther is wickidnesse of prudence, and cursidnesse is ther ynne; and ther is an vnwijs man, which is maad litil in wisdom.
Betere is a man that hath litil in wisdom, and failynge in wit in the drede of God, than he that hath plentee of wit, and brekith the lawe of the hiyeste.
Ther is certeyn sutilte, and it is wickid.
And ther is a man, that sendith out a certeyn word, tellynge out treuthe. Ther is a man, that mekith hym silf wickidly; and hise ynnere thingis ben ful of gile.
And ther is a iust man, that makith low greetli hym silf of myche mekenesse; and ther is a iust man, that bowith the face, and feyneth hym to se not that, that is vnknowun.
Thouy he is forbodun of feblenesse of strengthis to do synne; if he fyndith tyme to do yuele, he schal do yuel.
A man is knowun bi siyt; and a witti man is knowun bi meetyng of face.
The clothing of bodi, and the leiyyng of teeth, and the entring of a man, tellen out of hym.
Ther is fals repreuyng in the ire of a man ful of dispisyng; and ther is dom which is not preued to be good; and ther is a stille man, and he is prudent.
It is ful good to repreue, more than to be wrooth, and to forbede not a man knoulechyng in preiere.
The coueitise of a geldyng hath defoulid the maidynhed of a yong womman,
so he that makith wickid dom bi violence.
It is ful good, that a man `that is repreued schewe opynli penaunce; for so thou schalt ascape wilful synne.
Ther is a stil man, which is foundun wijs; and he is hateful, which is fool hardi to speke.
Sotheli ther is a stille man, not hauynge wit of speche; and ther is a stille man, knowynge the sesoun of couenable tyme.
A wijs man schal be stille til to tyme; but a ioli man and vnprudent man schulen not kepe tyme.
He that vsith many wordis, hirtith his soule; and he that takith power to hym silf vniustli, schal be hatid.
Ther is goyng forth in yuels to a man vnlernyd; and ther is fyndyng in to peiryng.
Ther is a yifte, which is not profitable; and ther is a yifte, whos yeldyng is double.
Ther is makyng lesse for glorie; and ther is a man, which schal reise the heed fro mekenesse.
Ther is a man, that ayen bieth many synnes for litil prijs, and restorith tho in seuenfold.
A wijs man in wordis makith hym silf amyable; but the graces of foolis schulen be sched out.
The yifte of an vnwijs man schal not be profitable to thee; for hise iyen ben seuenfold.
He schal yyue litle thingis, and he schal vpbreide many thingis; and the openyng of his mouth is enflawming.
To dai a man leeneth, and to morewe he axith; and siche a man is hateful.
A frend schal not be to a fool, and grace schal not be to hise goodis.
For thei that eten his breed, ben of fals tunge; hou ofte and hou many men schulen scorne hym?
For he departith not bi euene wit that, that was worthi to be had; in lijk maner and that, that was not worthi to be had.
The falling of a fals tunge is as he that fallith in the pawment; so the fallis of yuele men schulen come hastili.
A man with out grace is as a veyn fable; and it schal be customable in the mouth of vnlerned men.
A parable schal be repreued of the mouth of a fool; for he seith not it in his tyme. Ther is a man, that is forbodun to do synne, for pouert; and he schal be prickid in his reste.
Ther is a man, that schal leese his soule for schame; and for the vnprudence of a persoone he schal leese it.
Forsothe he schal leese hym silf for the takyng of a persoone.
Ther is a man, that for schame biheetith to a frend; and he hath gete hym enemy with out cause.
Leesyng is a wickid schenschip in a man; and it schal be customabli in the mouth of vnlerned men.
Betere is a theef than the customablenesse of a man, a leesyngmongere; forsothe bothe thei schulen enherite perdicioun.
The maneres of men leesyngmongeris ben with outen onour; and her schenschype is with hem with out ceessyng.
A wijs man in wordis schal brynge forth hym silf; and a prudent man schal pleese grete men.
He that worchith his lond, shal make hiy the heep of fruytis; and he that worchith riytfulnesse, schal be enhaunsid. Sotheli he that plesith grete men, schal ascape wickidnesse.
Presentis and yiftis blynden the iyen of iugis; and as doumb in the mouth it turneth awei the chastisyngis of hem.
Wisdom hid, and tresour vnseyn, what profit is in euer eithir?
He is betere, that hidith his vnwisdom, than a man that hidith his wisdom.
Sone, thou hast do synne? adde thou not eft; but biseche thou for the formere synnes, that tho be foryouun to thee.
As fro the face of a serpent fle thou synnes; and if thou neiyest to `tho synnes, tho schulen take thee.
The teeth of a lioun ben the teeth therof, that sleen the soulis of men.
Al wickidnesse is as a scharp swerd on either syde; heelthe is not to the wounde therof.
Chidyngis and wrongis schulen distrie catel; and an houe that is ouer riche, schal be distriede bi pride; so the catel of a proude man schal be drawun vp bi the roote.
The preyer of a pore man schal come fro the mouth `til to eeris; and doom schal come to hym hastili.
He that hatith repreuyng, is a step of the synnere; and he that dredith God, schal be turned to his herte.
A miyti man with an hardi tunge is knowun afer; and a witti man kan kepe him silf fro that man.
He that bildith his hous with othere mennus costis, is as he that gaderith hise stonys in wyntir.
Scheuys gaderid togidere is the synagoge of synneris; and the endyng of hem is the flawme of fier.
The weie of synneris is set togidere with stoonys; and in the ende of hem ben hellis, and derknessis, and peynes.
He that kepith riytfulnesse, schal holde the wit therof.
The perfeccioun of Goddis drede is wisdom and wit.
He schal not be tauyt, which is not wijs in good.
Forsothe vnwisdom is, which is plenteuouse in yuel; and wit is not, where is bittirnesse.
The kunnyng of a wijs man schal be plenteuouse as flowyng; and the councel of hym dwellith as a welle of lijf.
The herte of a fool is as a brokun vessel; and it schal not holde ony wisdom.
What euer wijs word a kunnynge man herith, he schal preise, and leie to. A letcherouse man herde, and it schal displese hym; and he schal caste it awei bihynde his bak.
The tellynge of a fool is as a birthun in the weie; for whi grace schal be foundun in the lippis of a wijs man.
The mouth of a prudent man is souyt in the chirche; and men schulen thenke hise wordis in her hertis.
As an hous distried, so is wisdom to a fool; and the kunnyng of an vnwijs man is wordis that moun not be teld out.
Stockis in the feet is techyng to a fool; and as bondis of hondis on the riyt hond.
A fool enhaunsith his vois in leiyyng; but a wijs man schal leiye vnnethis stilli.
Techyng is a goldun ournement to a prudent man; and as an ournement of the arm in the riyt arm.
The foot of a fool is liyt in to the hous of a neiybore; and a wijs man schal be aschamed of the persoone of a miyti man.
A fool biholdith fro the wyndow in to the hous; but a lerned man schal stonde with out forth.
It is foli of a man to herkene bi the dore; and a prudent man schal be greuyd bi dispisyng.
The lippis of `vnprudent men schulen telle fonned thingis; but the wordis of prudent men schulen be weied in a balaunce.
The herte of foolis is in her mouth; and the mouth of wise men is in her herte.
Whanne a wickid man cursith the deuel, he cursith his owne soule.
A priuy bacbitere schal defoule his soule, and in alle thingis he schal be hatid, and he that dwellith, schal be hatid; a stil man and wijs schal be onourid.
A slow man is stonyd in a stoon of cley; and alle men schulen speke on the dispisyng of him.
A slow man is stonyd of the dung of oxis; and ech man that touchith hym, schal schake the hondis.
The schame of a fadir is of a sone vnlerned; but a fonned douyter schal be in decreessyng.
A prudent douyter is eritage to hir hosebonde; for sche that schendith hir hosebonde, is in dispisyng of the fadir.
A `schameles womman schendith the fadir and hosebonde, and schal not be maad lesse than vnfeithful men; forsothe sche schal not be onourid of euer either.
Melodie in morenyng is vncouuenable tellyng; betyngis and techyng in al tyme with wisdom.
He that techith a fool, as he that glueth togidere a tiel stoon.
He that tellith a word to hym that herith not, is as he that reisith a man slepynge fro a greuouse sleep.
He that tellith wisdom to a fool, spekith with a man slepynge; and in the ende of the tellyng he schal seie, Who is this?
Wepe thou on a deed man, for whi his liyt failide; and wepe thou on a fool, for he failide of wit.
Wepe thou a litil on a deed man, for he hath restid.
Forsothe the lijf of a ful wickid man is ful wickid, more than the deth of a fool.
The morenyng of a deed man is seuene daies; but the morenyng of a fool and of a wickid man is alle the daies of her lijf.
Speke thou not myche with a fool, and go thou not with an vnwijs man.
Keep thee fro hym, that thou haue not disese; and thou schalt not be defoulid in the synne of hym.
Boowe thou awei fro hym, and thou schalt fynde reste; and be thou not anoied by his foly.
What schal be maad heuyere than leed? and what othere name than a fool is to it?
It is liytere to bere grauel, and salt, and a gobet of yrun, than a man vnprudent, and a fool, and vnfeithful.
As an heep of trees, boundun togidere in the foundement of the bilding, schal not be vnboundun, so and an herte confermed in the thouyt of counsel.
The thouyt of a wijs man shal not be maad schrewid in ony tyme, nether drede.
As chaffis in hiye places, and soond with out medling of hym, set ayens the face of wynd, schulen not dwelle;
so and a dreedful herte in the thouyt of a fool ayenstondith not ayens the feersnesse of drede.
As ournyng, ether pargetyng, ful of grauel in a cleer wal, so and a ferdful herte in the thouyt of a fool schal not drede in ony tyme; so and he that dwellith euere in the heestis of God.
He that prickith the iye, schal leede out teeris; and he that prickith the herte, bryngith forth wit.
He that castith a stoon to briddis, schal caste doun tho; so and he that doith wrong to a frend, departith frenschipe.
Thouy thou bryngist forth a swerd to a frend, dispeire thou not; for ther is going ayen to the frend.

If he openeth a soreuful mouth, drede thou not; for whi ther is acordyng, outakun dispisynge, and schenschipe, and pride, and schewyng of preuyte, and a tretcherouse wounde; in alle these thingis a frend schal fle awei.
Haue thou feith with a frend in his pouert, that thou be glad also in hise goodis.
In the tyme of his tribulacioun dwelle thou feithful to hym, that also thou be euene eir in the eritage of hym.
Heete and smook of fier is maad hiy bifore the fier of a chymenei; so and cursyngis, and dispisyngis, and manaassis, comen bifore blood.
I schal not be aschamed for to grete a frend, and Y schal not hide me fro his face; thouy yuels comen to me bi hym, Y schal suffre.
Ech man that schal here, schal kepe warli hym silf fro hym.
Who schal yyue keping to my mouth, and a certeyn ceelyng on my lippis, that Y falle not bi tho, and that my tunge leese not me?
Lord, fadir, and lordli gouernour of my lijf, forsake thou me not in the thouyt and counsel of hem; nether suffre thou me to falle in that schenschipe.
Who settith aboue in my thouyt beetyngis, and in myn hert the techyng of wisdom, that in the vnkunnyngis of hem he spare not me, and that the trespassis of hem appere not?
Lest myn vnkunnyngis encreesse, and my trespassis be multiplied, and my synnes be plenteuouse; and lest Y falle in the siyt of myn aduersaries, and myn enemy haue ioie.
Lord, fadir, and God of my lijf, forsake thou not me in the thouyt of hem.
Yyue thou not to me enhaunsyng of myn iyen; and turne thou awei fro me al schrewid desijr.
Do thou awei fro me the coueitisis of the wombe, and the coueitisis of letcherie take me not; and yyue thou not `me to a soule vnreuerent and vndiscreet.
Sones, here ye the techyng of mouth; and he that kepith it, schal not perische bi hise lippis, nether schal be
sclaundrid in worste werkis A synnere and proude man schal be takun in his vanite; and a cursid man schal be sclaundrid in tho.
Thy mouth be not customable to swering; for whi many fallyngis ben ther ynne.
Forsothe the nemyng of God be not customable in thi mouth, and be thou not meddlid to the names of seyntis; for thou schalt not be giltles of hem.
For as a seruaunt that is axid bisili, schal not wante wannesse; so ech man swerynge and nemynge schal not be purgid of synne in al.
A man swerynge myche schal be fillid with wickidnesse; and veniaunce schal not go awei fro his hous.
And if he disseyueth a brother, his trespas schal be aboue hym; and if he feyneth, he schal trespasse doubli.
And if he swerith in veyn, he schal not be iustified; for whi his hous schal be fillid with worst yelding.
Also ayenward another speche is in to deth; be it not found in the eritage of Jacob.
For whi alle these thingis schulen be don awei fro merciful men; and thei schulen not delite in trespassis.
Thi mouth be not customable to vnreuerent speche; for whi a word of synne is in it.
Haue thou mynde on thi fadir and modir; for thou stondist in the myddis of grete men.
Lest perauenture God foryete thee in the siyt of hem; and lest thou maad a fool bi thi customablenesse, suffre schenschipe, and haddist leuere to be not borun, and curse the dai of thi birthe.
A man customable in the wordis of schenschipe, in alle daies schal not be tauyt.
Twei kyndis ben plenteuouse in synnes, and the thridde bringith ire and perdicioun.
An hoot soule brennynge as fier schal not be quenchid, til it swolewe sum thing;
and a wickid man in the mouth of his fleisch schal not faile, til he kyndle fier.
Ech breed is swete to a letcherouse man; he schal not be maad weri, trespassynge `til to the ende.
Ech man that passith his bed, doith dispit ayens his soule, and seith, Who seeth me?
Derknessis cumpassen me, and wallis kyueren me, and no man biholdith me. Whom drede Y? The hiyeste schal not haue mynde on my synnes.

And he vndirstondith not, that the iye of him seeth alle thingis; for whi the drede of siche a man puttith awei fro him the drede of God, and the iyen of men that dreden hym putten awei fro hym Goddis drede.
And he knew not, that the iyen of the Lord ben myche more clerere than the sunne, and biholden alle the weies of men, and the depthe of the see, and biholden the hertis of men in to hid partis.
For whi alle thingis weren knowun to the Lord, bifore that thei weren maad of nouyt; so and aftir the makyng he biholdith alle thingis.
This man schal be punyschid in the stretis of the citee; he schal be dryuun a wei as an horse colt, and he schal be takun, where he hopith not.
And he schal be schenschip to alle men; for he vndurstood not the drede of the Lord.
So and ech womman forsakynge hir hosebonde schal do synne, and ordeynynge eritage of an alien matrimonye.

For firste sche was vnbileueful in the lawe of the hiyeste, and the secounde tyme sche forsook hir hosebonde; and the thridde tyme sche was defoulid in auowtrie, and ordeynede to hym sones of another man.
`This womman schal be brouyt in to the chirche, and me schal biholde on hir sones.
Hir sones schulen not yyue rootis, and hir braunchis schulen not yyue fruyt.
Thei schulen leeue the mynde of hir in to cursyng, and the schenschipe of hir schal not be don awei.
And thei that ben left schulen knowe, that no thing is betere than the drede of God, and nothing is swettere than to biholde in the comaundementis of the Lord.
It is greet glorie to sue the Lord; for whi lengthe of daies schulen be takun of hym.
Wisdom schal preise his soule, and he schal be onourid in God; and he schal haue glorie in the myddis of his puple.
And he schal opene his mouth in the chirchis of the hiyeste; and he schal haue glorie in the siyt of his vertu.
And he schal be enhaunsid in the myddis of his puple; and he schal wondre in hooli plentee.
And in the multitude of chosun men he schal haue preisyng; and among blessid men he schal be blessid,
and seie, I, the firste gendrid bifore ech creature, cam forth fro the mouth of the hiyeste.
I made in heuenes, that liyt neuere failynge roos vp, and as a cloude Y hilide al erthe.
Y dwellide in hiyeste thingis, and my trone in a piler of cloude.
Y aloone yede aboute the cumpas of heuene, and Y perside the depthe of the see; and Y yede in the wawis of the see,
and Y stood in al the lond.
And Y hadde the firste dignite in ech puple, and in ech folk;
and Y trad bi vertu on the neckis of alle excelent men and meke; and in alle these men Y souyte reste, and Y schal dwelle in the eritage of the Lord.
Thanne the creatour of alle comaundide, and seide to me; and he that formyde me, restide in my tabernacle; and he seide to me,
Dwelle thou in Jacob, and take thou eritage in Israel, and sende thou rootis in my chosun men.
Y was gendrid of the bigynnyng and bifore worldis, and Y schal not faile `til to the world to comynge; and Y mynystride in an hooli dwellyng bifore hym.
And so Y was maad stidfast in Syon, and in lijk maner Y restide in a citee halewid, and my power was in Jerusalem.
And Y rootid in a puple onourid; and the eritage therof in to the partis of my God, and my witholding in the plentee of seyntis.
Y was enhaunsid as a cedre in Liban, and as a cipresse tree in the hil of Syon.
Y was enhaunsid as a palm tree in Cades, and as the plauntyng of roose in Jeryco.
As a fair olyue tree in feeldis; and Y was enhaunsid as a plane tree bisidis watir in stretis.
As canel and bawme yyuynge greet smelle, Y yaf odour; as chosun myrre Y yaf the swetnesse of odour.
And as storax, and galban, and vngula, and gumme, and as Liban not kit doun, Y made hoot my dwellyng place; and myn odour as bawme not meddlid.
Y as a terebynte stretchide forth my boowis; and my boowis ben boowis of onour, and of glorie.
Y as a vyne made fruyt the swetnesse of odour; and my flouris ben the fruytis of onour, and of oneste.
I am a modir of fair loue, and of drede, and of knowyng, and of hooli hope.
In me is al grace of weie, and of treuthe; in me is al hope of lijf and of vertu.
Alle ye that coueiten me, passe to me; and be ye fillid of my generaciouns.
For whi my spirit is swete aboue hony; and myn eritage is aboue hony, and hony comb.
My mynde is in the generacioun of worldis.
Thei that eten me, schulen hungre yit; and thei that drynken me, schulen thirste yit.
He that herith me, shal not be schent; and thei that worchen in me, schulen not do synne; and thei that declaren me,
schulen haue euere lastynge lijf.
Alle these thingis is the book of lijf, and the testament of the hiyeste, and the knowyng of treuthe.
Moises comaundide a lawe in the comaundementis of riytfulnessis, and eritage to the hous of Jacob, and biheestis to Israel.
He settide to Dauid, his child, to reise of hym a kyng moost strong, and sittynge with outen ende in the trone of onour.
Which kyng fillith wisdom, as Phison schedith out watir; and as Tigris in the daies of newe thingis.
Which, as Eufrates, fillith wit; which multiplieth, as Jordan in the tyme of heruest.
Which sendith techyng as liyt; and is niy alle men, as Gion in the dai of vendage.
Which makith perfitli first to knowe that wisdom; and a feblere man schal not enserche it.
For whi the thouyt therof schal be plenteuouse of the see; and his counsel in the greet occian.
Y wisdom schedde out floodis;
Y as a weie of ful greet watir of the flood. Y as the flood Dorix, and as a watir cundit Y yede out of paradis.
Y seide, I schal watir my gardyn of plauntyngis; and Y schal greetli fille the fruyt of my child beryng.
And lo! a plenteuouse weie of watir is maad to me; and my flood neiyede to the see.
For Y liytne techyng as the cheer morewtid to alle men; and Y schal telle out it `til to fer.
Y schal perse alle the lowere partis of erthe, and Y schal biholde alle that slepen; and Y schal liytne alle that hopen in the Lord.
Yit Y schal schede out teching as profesie, and Y schal leeue it to hem that seken wisdom; and Y schal not faile in to the generaciouns of hem, til in to the hooli world.
Se ye, that Y trauelide not to me aloone, but to alle that seken out treuthe.
In thre thingis it is plesid to my spirit, which ben appreued bifore God and men; acordyng of britheren,
and loue of neiyboris, a man and womman wel consentynge to hem silf.
My soule hatide thre spicis, and Y am greued greetli to the soule of hem;
a pore man proud, and a riche man liere, and an eld man a fool and vnwitti.
Hou schalt thou fynde in thin eelde tho thingis, whiche thou gaderist not in thi yongthe?
Doom is ful fair in hoornesse, and to preestis to knowe councel.
Wisdom is ful fair to eelde men, and gloriouse vndirstondyng, and councel.
The coroun of eelde men is in myche kunnyng; and the glorie of hem is the drede of God.
I magnefiede nyne thingis vnsuspect of the herte; and Y schal seie the tenthe thing bi tunge to men.
A man which lyuynge is myrie in sones, and seynge the distriyng of hise enemyes.
He is blessid that dwellith with a witty womman, and he that felle not bi his tunge, and he that seruyde not to men vnworthi to hym silf.
He is blessid that fyndith a very frend, and he that tellith out riytfulnesse to an eere heringe.
He is ful greet that fyndith wisdom and kunnyng; but he is not aboue him that dredith God.
The drede of God hath set it silf aboue alle thingis.
Blessid is the man to whom it is youun to have the drede of God; to whom schal he be licned, that holdith that drede?
The drede of God is the bigynnyng of his loue; forsothe the bigynnyng of feith is to be faste ioyned therto.
The sorewe of herte is ech wounde; and the wickidnesse of a womman is al malice.
A leche shal se ech wounde, and not the wounde of herte; and al wickidnesse,
and not the wickidnesse of a womman;
and ech hilyng, and not hilyng of hateris;
and ech veniaunce, and not the veniaunce of enemyes.
Noon heed is worse than the heed of an eddre dwellynge in schadewe;
and noon ire is aboue the ire of a womman. It schal plese more to dwelle with a lioun and a dragoun, than to dwelle with a wickid womman.
The wickidnesse of a womman chaungith hir face; and sche blyndide her cheer as a beer doith, and sche schal schewe as a sak in the myddis of neiyboris.
