Hir hosebonde weilide; and his wickid wijf herde, and siyyide a litil.
Al malice is schort on the malice of a womman; the parte of synneris falle on hir.
As a stiynge ful of grauel in the feet of an elde man, so is a womman a greet ianglere to a pesible man.
Biholde thou not the fairnesse of a womman, and coueyte thou not a womman for fairnesse.
The ire and vnreuerence of a womman is grete schenschipe.
If a womman hath the firste dignyte, ethir cheef gouernail, sche is contrarie to hir hosebonde.
A low herte, and soreuful face, and wounde of deeth, is a wickid womman.
Feble hondis and knees vnboundun, a womman that blessith not hir hosebonde.
The bygynnyng of synne was maad of a womman; and alle we dien bi hir.
Yyue thou not issu to thi watir, yhe, not a litil issu; nether to a wickid womman fredom of goyng forth.
If sche goith not at thin hond, sche schal schende thee in the siyt of enemyes.
Kitte hir a wei fro thi fleischis, lest euere sche mysvse thee.
The hosebonde of a good womman is blessid; for whi the noumbre of her yeeris is double.
A strong womman delitith hir hosebonde; and shal fille in pees the yeeris of his lijf.
A good womman is a good part; in the good part of hem that dreden God, sche schal be youun to a man for goode dedis.
Forsothe the herte of a riche man and of a pore man is good; in al tyme her cheer is glad.
Myn herte dredde of thre thingis, and my face dredde in the fourthe thing.
Bitraiyng of a citee, and the gadering togidere of puple,
and fals chaleng; alle thingis greuouse on deth.
The sorewe of herte, and morenyng is a ielouse womman.
In a gelouse womman is betyng of tunge, and sche comyneth with alle men.
As a yok of oxis which is mouyd, so and a wickid womman; he that holdith hir, is as he that takith a scorpioun.
A drunkelew womman is greet ire, and dispisyng; and hir filthe schal not be hilid.
The fornycacioun of a womman is in the reisyng of yyen; and schal be knowun in the iye liddis of hir.
Make thou sad kepyng in a douytir not turnynge a wei hir silf; lest sche mysvse hir silf, if sche fyndith occasioun.
Be thou war of al vnreuerence of hir iyen; and wondre thou not, if sche dispisith thee.

As a weiegoere thirstynge schal opene the mouth at a welle, and schal drynke of ech watir next; and the forseid douytir schal sitte ayens ech pale, and schal opene the arowe caas ayens ech arowe, til sche faile.
The grace of a bisi womman schal delite hir hosebonde; and schal make fat hise boonus.
The kunnyng of hir is the yifte of God.
A wijs womman and stille is not chaungyng of a lernyd soule.
Grace on grace is an hooli womman, and schamfast.
Forsothe al weiyng is not worth a contynent soule.
As the sunne risynge in the world in the hiyeste thingis of God, so the fairnesse of a good womman is in to the ournement of hir hous.
A lanterne schynynge on an hooli candilstike, and the fairnesse of a face on stidfast age.
Goldun pileris on siluerne foundementis, and stidfast feet on the soolis of a stidfast womman.
Euerlastynge foundementis on a sad stoon, and the heestis of God in the herte of an hooli womman.
In twei thingis myn herte was maad sori, and in the thridde thing wrathfulnesse cam to me.
A man a werriour failynge bi nedynesse, and a wijs man dispisid.
And God hath maad hym redi to the swerd, that passith ouer fro riytfulnesse to synne.
Twei spices apperiden harde and perilouse to me; a marchaunt is delyuered of hard fro his necgligence, and a tauerner schal not be iustified of synnes of lippis.
Many men han trespassid for nedynesse; and he that sekith to be maad riche, turneth a wei his iye.
As a stake is fastned in the myddis of a heep of stoonys, so and a man schal be angwischid bi synnes bitwixe the middis of sillyng and biyng.
Trespas schal be al to-brokun with hym that trespassith.
If thou holdist not thee diligentli in the drede of the Lord, thin hous schal soone be turned vpsedoun.
As dust schal dwelle in the hoolis of a riddil, so the angwisch of a man schal dwelle in the thouyt of hym.
A furneis preueth the vessels of a pottere; and the temptacioun of tribulacioun preueth iust men.
As cherliche trauel aboute a tree schewith the fruyt therof, so a word of thouyt schewith the herte of man.
Preise thou not a man bifore a word; for whi this is the temptacioun of men.

If thou suest riytfulnesse, thou schalt take it; thou schalt clothe it as a long cloth of onour, and thou schalt dwelle with it, and it schal defende thee with outen ende, and in the dai of knowing thou shalt fynde stidfastnesse.
Volatilis comen togidere to briddis lijk hem silf; and treuthe schal turne ayen to hem that worchen it.
A lioun settith aspies euere to huntyng; so synnes to hem that worchen wickidnesse.
An hooly man dwellith in wisdom, as the sunne dwellith stabli; for whi a fool is chaungid as the moone.
In the myddis of vnwise men kepe thou a word to tyme; but be thou bisi in the myddis of hem that thenken the lawe of God.
The tellyng of synneris is hateful; and the leiyyng of hem is in the trespassis of synne.
Speche sweringe myche schal make stondyng up of heeris, for astonying, to the heed; and vnreuerence therof is stoppyng of eeris.
The schedyng out of blood is in the chidyng of proude men; and the cursyng of hem is greuouse heryng.
He that schewith opynli the priuytees of a frend, leesith feithfulnesse; and he schal not fynde a frend to his soule.
Loue thou a neiybore, and be thou ioyned with hym in feith.
For if thou schewist opynli the priuytees of hym, thou schalt not perfitli sue aftir hym.
For as a man that leesith his frend, so he that leesith the frenschipe of his neiybore.
And as a man that latith go a brid fro his hond, so thou that hast forsake thi neiybore, and thou schalt not take hym.
Thou schalt not sue hym, for he is fer absent; for he ascapid as a capret fro a snare, for the soule of hym is woundid.
Thou schalt no more mow bynde hym togidere; but of yuel seiyng is acordyng.
Sotheli to schewe opynli the pryuytees of a frend, is dispeir of a soule vnblessid.
He that twynclith with the iye, makith wickid thingis;

and no man schal caste hym awei. In the siyt of thin iyen he schal defoule his mouth, and he schal wondre on thi wordis; but at the laste he schal turne weiwerdli his mouth, and in his wordis he schal yyue sclaundre.
Y herde mani thingis, and Y made not euene to hym; and the Lord schal hate hym.
If a man throwith a stoon an hiy, it schal falle on his heed; and the gileful wounde of a gyleful man schal departe woundis.
And he that diggith a diche, schal falle in to it; and he that settith a stoon to a neiybore, schal offende therynne; and he that settith a snare to a nother man, schal perische ther ynne.
If a man makith worst councel, it schal be turned on hym; and he schal not knowe fro whennus it schal come to him.
The scornyng and dispisyng of proude men and veniaunce schal sette a spie to hym, as a lioun doith.
Thei that deliten in the fal of iust men, schulen perische bi a snare; forsothe sorewe schal waste hem, bifore that thei dien.
Ire and woodnesse, euer either ben abhomynable; and a synful man schal holde tho.
He that wole be vengid, schal fynde of the Lord veniaunce; and he kepynge schal kepe hise synnes.
Foryyue thou to thi neiybore that anoieth thee, and thanne synnes schulen be releessid to thee preiynge.
A man kepith ire to man; and sekith he of God medicyn?
He hath no merci on a man lijk hym silf; and bisechith he the hiyeste for hise owne synnes?
He the while he is fleisch, reserueth ire; and axith he of God merci? who schal preie for hise synnes?
Haue thou mynde on the laste thingis, and ceesse thou to be enemy.
For whi failyng and deth neiyen not in the comaundementis of God.
Haue thou mynde on the drede of the Lord, and be thou not wrooth to the neiybore.
Haue thou mynde on the testament of the hiyeste, and dispise thou the ignoraunce of thi neiybore.
Absteyne thee fro strijf, and thou schalt abregge synnes.
For whi a wrathful man kyndlith strijf; and a synful man schal disturble frendis, and he schal sende in enemyte in the myddis of men hauynge pees.
For whi aftir the trees of the wode, so fier schal brenne an hiy; and after the myyte of a man, so his wrathfulnesse schal be, and aftir his catel he schal enhaunse his ire.
Hasti stryuyng schal kyndle fier, and hasti chidyng schal schede out blood; and a tunge berynge witnessing schal brynge deth.
If thou blowist, as fier it schal brenne an hiy; and if thou spetist theron, it schal be quenchid; euer either comen forth of the mouth.
A preuy bacbiter, and a double tungid man is cursid; for he disturblide many men hauynge pees.
The thridde tunge hath stirid many men, and hath scaterid hem fro folc in to folc.
It hath distried wallid citees of riche men, and hath myned doun the housis of grete men.
It hath kit doun the vertues of puplis, and hath vnknit strong folkis.
The thridde tunge hath cast out weddid wymmen, and hath priued hem of her trauelis.
He that biholdith the thridde tunge, schal not haue rest; nether schal haue a frend, in whom he schal reste.
The wounde of betyng makith wannesse; but the wounde of tunge schal make lesse the boonys.
Many men fellen doun bi the scharpnesse of swerd; but not so as thei that perischiden bi her tunge.
He is blessid that is kyuerid fro a wickid tunge; and he that passide not in the wrathfulnesse therof, and he that drow not the yok therof, and was not boundun in the bondis therof.
For whi the yok therof is an irun yok, and the boond therof is a brasun boond.
The deth therof is the worste deth; and helle is more profitable than it.
The perseueraunce therof schal not dwelle, but it schal holde the weies of vniust men; in his flawme it schal not brenne iust men.
Thei that forsaken God, schulen falle in to it; and it schal brenne greetli in hem, and it schal not be quenchid; and as a lioun it schal be sent in to hem, and as a parde it schal hirte hem.
Bisette thin eeris with thornes, and nyle thou here a wickid tunge; and make thou doris to thi mouth, and lockis to thin eeris.
Welle thou togidere thi gold, and thi siluer; and make thou a balaunce to thi wordis, and riytful bridels to thi mouth.
And take heede, lest perauenture thou slide in tunge, and falle in the siyt of enemyes, settynge tresoun to thee, and thi falle be vncurable in to deth.
He that doith merci, leeneth to his neiybore; and he that is ful myyti in hond, kepith the comaundementis.
Leene thou to thi neiybore in the tyme of his nede; and eft yelde thou to a neiybore in his tyme.
Conferme thou a word, and do thou feithfuli with hym; and in al tyme thou schalt fynde that, that is nedeful to thee.
Many men gessiden borewyng as fyndyng, and yauen disese to tho men that helpiden hem.
Til thei taken, thei kissen the hondis of the yyuer; and in biheestis thei maken meke her vois.
And in the time of yelding he schal axe tyme, and he schal speke wordis of anoie, and of grutchingis, and he schal calenge falsli the tyme.
Forsothe if he mai yelde, he schal be aduersarie; of a schilling vnnethis he schal yelde the half, and he schal rekyn that as fyndyng.
Ellis he schal defraude him in his monei, and the leenere schal haue him an enemy with outen cause.
And he schal yelde to hym, that is, to the leenere, wrongis and cursyngis; and for onour and benefice he schal yelde to hym dispisyng.
Many men lenten not `to pore neiyboris, not for cause of wickidnesse, but thei dredden to be defraudid with outen cause.
Netheles on a meke man in soule be thou strongere; and for almes drawe thou not hym.
For the comaundement of God take thou a pore man; and for his nedynesse leeue thou not hym voide.
Leese thou monei for a brother and frend, and hide thou not it vndur a stoon, in to perdicioun.
Putte thi tresour in the comaundementis of the hiyeste; and it schal profite to thee more than gold `schal profite.
Close thou almes in the bosum of a pore man; and this almes schal preye for thee `to be delyuered of God fro al yuel.
The almes of a man is as a bagge with hym; and it schal kepe the grace of man as the appil of the iye.
And aftirward it schal rise ayen, and schal yelde to hem a yelding, to ech man in to the heed of hem.
Aboue a scheld of the myyti man, and aboue a spere it schal fiyte ayens thin enemye.
A good man makith feith to his neiybore; and he that leesith, schal leeue schame to hym.
Foryete thou not the grace of the borewe; for he yaf his lijf for thee.
A synful man and vncleene fleeth the biheetere.
A synnere arretteth to hym silf the goode wordis of the borowe; and the vnkynde man in wit forsakith a man delyuerynge hym.
A man biheetith for his neiybore; and whanne `the neiybore hath lost reuerence, the borew schal be forsakun of hym.
Worst biheest hath lost many louynge men, and hath moued hem as the wawis of the see.
It goynge in cumpas made myyti men to passe ouer; and thei wandriden aboute among alien folkis.
A synnere brekynge the comaundement of the Lord schal falle in to a wickid biheest; and he that enforsith to do many thingis, schal falle in to dom.
Rekiuere thi neiybore bi thi vertu; and take heed to thi silf, lest thou falle.
The bigynnyng of lijf of a man is watir, and breed, and clothing, and hous hilynge filthe.
Betere is the lijflode of a pore man vndur the hilyng of sparris, than schynynge feestis in pilgrymage with outen hous.
The leeste thing pleese thee for a greet thing; and thou schalt not here the schenschipe of pilgrymage.
It is wickid lijf to seke herbore fro hous in to hous; and where he schal be herborid, he schal not do tristili, nethir he schal opene the mouth.
He schal be herborid, and he schal feede, and yyue drinke to vnkynde men; and yit he schal here bittir thingis.
Passe, thou that art herborid, and araye a table; and yyue thou meetis to othere men, tho thingis that thou hast in the hond.
Go thou out fro the face of the onour of my frendis, for the frendschipe, ethir affinyte, of myn hous; bi herboryng thou art maad a brother to me.
These thingis ben greuouse to a man hauynge wit; the repreuyng of hous, and the dispising of the vsurer.
He that loueth his sone, yyueth bisili betingis to hym, that he be glad in hise laste thing, and that the sone touche not the doris of neiyboris.
He that techith his sone, schal be preisid in hym; and schal haue glorie in hym in the myddis of menyals.
He that techith his sone, sendith the enemye in to enuye; and in the myddis of frendis he schal haue glorie in that sone.
The fadir of hym is deed, and he is as not deed; for he hath left aftir hym a sone lijk hym.
He siy in his lijf, and was glad in hym; and in his deth he was not sori, nether was aschamed bifore enemyes.
For he lefte a defendere of the hous ayens enemyes; and yeldynge grace to frendis.
For the soulis of sones he schal bynde togidere hise woundis; and hise entrails schulen be disturblid on ech vois.
An hors vntemyd, `ether vnchastisid, schal ascape hard, and a sone vnchastisid schal ascape heedi.
Flatere thou the sone, and he schal make thee dredinge; pleie thou with hym, and he schal make thee sory.
Leiye thou not with hym, lest thou haue sorewe togidere, and at the laste thi teeth schulen be astonyed.
Yyue thou not power to hym in yongthe, and dispise thou not hise thouytis.
Boowe thou his necke in yongthe, and bete thou hise sidis, while he is a yong child; lest perauenture he wexe hard, and bileue not to thee, and he schal be sorewe of soule to thee.
Teche thi sone, and worche in hym; lest thou offende in to the filthe of hym.
Betere is a pore man hool, and strong in myytis, than a riche man feble, and betun with malice.
The helthe of soule is in the hoolynesse of riytfulnesse, and it is betere than ony gold and siluer; and a strong bodi is betere than ful myche catel.
No catel is aboue the catel of helthe of bodi; and no likyng is aboue the ioie of herte.
Betere is deth than bittir lijf, and euerlastinge reste is betere than siknesse dwellynge contynueli.
Goodis hid in a closid mouth ben as settyngis forth of metis set aboute a sepulcre.
What schal sacrifice profite to an idol? for whi it schal not ete, nether schal smelle.
So he that is dryuun awei fro the Lord, and berith the medis of wickidnesse,
seynge with iyen and weilynge inwardli, as a geldynge biclippynge a virgyn, and siyyynge.
Yyue thou not sorewe to thi soule, and turmente not thi silf in thi counsel.
Mirthe of herte, this is the lijf of man, and is tresour of hoolynesse with outen failyng; and ful out ioiyng of a man is long lijf.
Haue thou mercy on thi soule, and plese thou God; and holde togidere and gadere togidere thin herte in the hoolynesse of hym, and putte fer awei sorewe fro thee.
For whi sorewe hath slayn many men; and noon heelthe is ther ynne.
Enuye and wrathfulnesse schulen make lesse daies; and thouytys schulen brynge eldnesse bifore the tyme.
A schynynge herte is good in metis; for whi meetis therof ben maad diligentli.
Wakyng of oneste schal make fleischis to faile; and thouyt therof schal take awei sleep.
Thouyt of bifore knowyng turneth awey wit; and greuouse siknesse makith sobre the soule.
A ryche man trauelide in the gaderyng of catel; and in his reste he schal be fillyd with hise goodis.
A pore man trauelide in decreessyng of lijflode; and in the ende he is maad nedi.
He that loueth gold, schal not be iustified; and he that sueth wastyng, schal be fillid therof.
Many men ben youun in to the fallyngis of gold; and the perdicioun of hem was maad in the feirnesse therof.
A tre of offencioun is the gold of hem that maken sacrifice; wo to hem that suen it, and ech vnprudent man schal perische ther ynne.
Blissid is a riche man, which is foundun with out wem; and that yede not aftir gold, nether hopide in money, and tresouris.
Who is this, and we schulen preyse hym? for he dide merueils in his lijf.
Which is preued ther ynne, and is foundun perfit, and euerlastynge glorye schal be to hym? which myyte trespasse, and trespasside not, and do yuels, and dide not.
Therfor hise goodis ben stablischid in the Lord; and al the chirche of seyntis schal telle out hise almesdedis.
Thou hast sete at a greet boord; opene thou not firste thi cheke on it.
Seie thou not, whether tho ben many thingis, that ben on it.
Haue thou mynde, that an yuel iye is weiward.
What thing worse, than an iye is maad? therfor of al his face he schal wepe, whanne he seeth.
Stretche thou not forth first thin hond; and thou defoulid bi enuye, be aschamed.
Be thou not oppressid of wyn in a feeste.
Vnderstonde of thi silf the thingis, that ben of thi neiybore.
Vse thou as a discreet and temperat man these thingis that ben set forth to thee; and be thou not hatid, whanne thou etist myche.
Ceesse thou first bicause of lernyng, ethir nurture; and nyle thou be outrageouse, lest perauenture thou offende.
And if thou hast sete in the myddis of many men, stretche not forth thin hond sunnere than thei; and axe thou not firste for to drynke.
A litil wyn is ful sufficient to a lerned man; and in slepynge thou schalt not trauele for that wyn, and thou schalt not feele trauel.
Wakyng, and colre, ether bittir moisture, and gnawyng to an vndiscreet `either vntemperat man.
But the sleep of heelthe is in a scars man; he schal slepe `til to the morewtid, and his soule schal delite with hym.
And if thou art constreyned in etyng myche, ryse thou fro the myddis, and brake thou; and it schal refreische thee, and thou schalt not brynge sikenesse to thi bodi.
Sone, here thou me, and dispise thou not me; and at the laste thou schalt fynde my wordis.
In alle thi werkis be thou swift; and al sikenesse schal not come to thee.
The lippis of many men schulen blesse a schynynge man in looues; and the witnessyng of his treuthe is feithful.
The citee schal grutche in the worste breed; and the witnessyng of wickidnesse therof is soth.
Nyle thou excite hem that ben diligent in wyn; for whi wyn hath distried many men.
Fier preueth hard irun; so wyn drunkun in drunkenesse schal repreue the hertis of proude men.
Euene lijf to men is wyn drunkun in sobrenesse; if thou drynkist it mesurably, thou schalt be sobre.
What is the lijf which is maad lesse bi wyn?
What defraudith lijf? deth.
Wyn was maad in gladnesse, not in drunkenesse, at the bigynnyng.
Wyn drunkun mesurabli is ful out ioiyng of soule and of bodi.
Sobre drynk is helthe of soule and of bodi.
Wyn drunkun myche makith avoiding, and ire, and many fallyngis.
Wyn drunkun myche is bitternesse of soule.
Strengthe of drunkenesse and hirting of an vnprudent man makith vertu lesse, and makynge woundis.
In the feeste of wyn repreue thou not a neiybore; and dispise thou not hym in his mirthe.
Seye thou not wordis of schenschipe to hym; and oppresse thou not hym in axynge.
Thei han set thee a gouernour, nyle thou be enhaunsid; be thou among hem as oon of hem.
Haue thou cure of hem, and so biholde thou; and whanne al thi cure is fillid, sitte thou to mete.
That thou be glad for hem, and take the ournement of grace; and gete coroun, and dignyte of congregacioun.
Speke thou the gretter man in birthe;
for whi the word of hym that loueth kunnyng bicome thee first; and lette thou not musik.
Where heryng is not, schede thou not out a word; and nyle thou be enhaunsid vncouenabli in thi wisdom.
A iemme of carbuncle in the ournement of gold; and comparisoun of musikis in the feeste of wyn.
As in the makyng of gold is a signe of smaragde, so the noumbre of musikis is in myrie and mesurable wyn.
Here thou stille, and good grace schal come to thee for reuerence.
Yonge man, speke thou vnnethis in thi cause, whanne nede is.
If thou art axid twies, the heed haue thin answere.
In many thingis be thou as vnkunnyng, and here thou stille togidere and axynge.
And presume thou not to speke in the myddis of grete men; and where elde men ben, speke thou not myche.
Leityng schal go bifore hail, and grace schal go bifore schamfastnesse, and good grace schal come to thee for reuerence.
And in the our of risyng tifle thee not; forsothe renne thou bifore first in to thin hous, and there clepe thou thee to answer, and there pleie thou.
And do thi conseitis, and not in synnes, and in a proud word.
On alle these thingis blesse thou the Lord, that made thee, and fillynge thee greetli of alle hise goodis.
He that dredith God, schal take his techyng; and thei that waken to hym, schulen fynde blessyng.
He that sekith the lawe, schal be fillid therof; and he that doith tretourousli, schal be sclaundrid ther ynne.
Thei that dreden God, schulen fynde iust dom; and schulen kyndle riytfulnesse as liyt.
A synful man schal eschewe blamyng; and aftir his wille he schal fynde comparisoun.
A man of counsel schal not leese vndirstonding; a man alien and proud schal not drede dredyng.
Yhe, aftir that he hath do with that drede with out councel, and he schal be repreued bi hise suyngis.
Sone, do thou no thing with out councel; and aftir the dede thou schalt not repente.
Go thou not in the weie of fallyng, and offende thou not ayens stoonys. Bitake thou not thee to a trauelouse weie, lest thou sette sclaundir to thi soule;
and be thou war of thi sones, and perseyue thou of thi meyneals.
In al thi werk bileue thou bi feith of thi soule; for whi this is the keping of comaundementis.
He that bileueth to God, takith heede to the comaundementis; and he that tristith in hym, schal not be maad lesse.
Iuelis schulen not come to hym that dredith God; but God schal kepe hym in temptacioun, and schal delyuere fro yuelis.
A wijs man hatith not the comaundementis, and riytfulnessis; and he schal not be hurtlid doun, as in the tempest of a schip.
A wijs man bileeueth to the lawe of God, and the lawe is feithful to hym.
He that makith opene axyng, schal make redi a word; and so he schal preie, and schal be herd, and he schal kepe techyng, and thanne he schal answere.
The entraylis of a fool ben as a wheel of a carte, and his thouytis as an extre able to turne aboute.
An hors a staloun, so and a frend a scornere, neiyeth vndur ech sittynge aboue.
Whi a dai ouercometh a dai, and eft the liyt ouercometh liyt, and a yeer ouercometh a yeer, the sunne ouercometh the sunne?
Tho ben departid of the kunnyng of the Lord, bi the sunne maad, and kepynge the comaundement of God.
And it schal chaunge tymes and the feeste daies of hem, and in tho tymes the Jewis halewiden hali daies at an our.
God enhaunside and magnyfiede of tho hali daies; and of tho he settide in to the noumbre of daies; and God made alle men of sad erthe, and of neische erthe, whereof Adam was formed.
In the multitude of kunnyng of the Lord he departide hem, and chaungide the weies of hem.
Of hem God blesside, and enhaunside; and of hem he halewide, and chees to hym silf; of hem he curside, and made lowe, and turnyde hem fro the departyng of hem.
As cley of a pottere is in the hond of hym,
to make and dispose, that alle the weies therof ben aftir the ordynaunce of hym; so a man is in the hond of hym that made hym; and he schal yelde to hym bi his dom.
Ayens yuel is good, and ayens lijf is deth; so and a synnere is ayens a iust man. And so biholde thou in to alle the werkis of the hiyeste; twey thingis ayens tweyne, and o thing ayens oon.
And Y the laste wakide, and as he that gaderith draf of grapis, aftir the gadereris of grapis.
And Y hopide in the blessyng of God; and as he that gaderith grapis, Y fillide the pressour.
Biholde ye, for Y trauelide not to me aloone, but to alle that seken kunnyng.
Grete men, and alle puplis, here ye me; and ye gouernouris of the chirche, perseyue with eeris.

Yyue thou not power ouer thee in thi lijf to a sone, and to a womman, to a brothir, and to a freend; and yyue thou not thi possessioun to another man, lest perauenture it repente thee, and thou biseche for tho.
While thou art alyue, and brethist yit, ech man schal not chaunge thee.
For it is betere, that thi sones preye thee, than that thou biholde in to the hondis of thi sones.
In alle thi werkis be thou souereyn;
yyue thou not a wem in to thi glorie. In the day of endyng of daies of thi lijf, and in tyme of thi goyng out departe thin erytage.
Metis, and a yerde, and birthun to an asse; breed, and chastisyng, and werk to a seruaunt.
He worchith in chastisyng, and sekith to haue reste; slake thou hondis to hym, and he sekith fredom.
A yok and bridil bowen doun an hard necke; and bisi worchingis bowen doun a seruaunt.
Turment and stockis to an yuel willid seruaunt; sende thou hym in to worchyng, lest he be ydel;
for whi idilnesse hath tauyte miche malice.
Ordeyne thou hym in werk, for so it bicometh hym; that if he obeieth not, bowe thou doun hym in stockis, and make thou not hym large ouer ony man, but with out dom do thou no thing greuouse.
If a feithful seruaunt is to thee, be he as thi soule to thee; trete thou him so as a brother, for thou hast bouyt hym in the blood of lijf.
If thou hurtist hym vniustli, he schal be turned in to fleyng awei;
and if he enhaunsynge goith awei, thou noost whom thou schalt seke, and in what weie thou schalt seke hym.
Veyn hope and a leesyng to an vnwijs man; and dremes enhaunsen vnprudent men.
As he that takith schadewe, and pursueth wynd, so and he that takith heede to leesyngis seyn.
Vpe this thing is the siyt of dremes; bifore the face of a man is the licnesse of another man.
What schal be clensid of him that is vnclene, and what trewe thing schal be seid of a liere?
Fals dyuynyng of errour, and fals dyuynyngis bi chiteryng of briddis, and dremes of witchis, is vanyte.
And as the herte of a womman trauelynge of child, thin herte suffrith fantasies; no but visitacioun is sent out of the hiyeste, yyue thou not thin herte in tho dremes.
For whi dremes han maad many men for to erre, and men hopynge in tho fellen doun.
The word of the lawe `of God and of hise profetis, schal be maad perfit with out leesyng; and wisdom in the mouth of a feithful man schal be maad pleyn.
What kan he, that is not asaied? A man asaied in many thingis, schal thenke many thingis; and he that lernyde many thingis, schal telle out vndirstondyng.
He that is not asaied, knowith fewe thingis; forsothe he that is a fool in many thingis, schal multiplie malice.
What maner thingis kan he, that is not asaied? He that is not plauntid, schal be plenteuouse in wickidnesse.
I siy many thingis in tellyng out, and ful many customs of wordis.
Sum tyme Y was in perel `til to deth, for the cause of these thingis; and Y was delyuered bi the grace of God.
The spirit of hem that dreden God is souyt, and schal be blessid in the biholding of hym.
For whi the hope of hem is in to God sauynge hem; and the iyen of the Lord ben in to hem, that louen hym.
He that dredith God, schal not tremble for ony thing, and he schal not drede; for whi God is his hope.
The soule of hym that dredith the Lord, is blessid.
To whom biholdith he, and who is his strengthe?
The iyen of the Lord ben on hem that dreden hym. God is a defendere of myyt, stidfastnesse of vertu, hilyng of heete, and a schadewyng place of myddai;
bisechyng of offendyng, and help of fallyng, enhaunsynge the soule, and liytnynge the iyen, and yyuynge heelthe, and lijf, and blessyng.
The offryng of hym that offrith of wickid thing, is defoulid; and the scornyngis of vniust men ben not wel plesaunt.
The Lord aloone is to hem that abiden hym in the weie of treuthe, and of riytfulnesse.
The hiyeste appreueth not the yiftis of wickid men, nethir biholdith in the offryngis of wickid men, nether in the multitude of her sacrifices he schal do mercy to synnes.
He that offrith sacrifice of the catel of pore men, is as he that sleeth the sone in the siyt of his fadir.
The breed of nedi men is the lijf of a pore man; he that defraudith hym, is a man of blood.
He that takith awei breed in swoot, is as he that sleeth his neiybore.
He that schedith out blood, and he that doith fraude to an hirid man, ben britheren.
Oon bildynge, and oon distriynge; what profitith it to hem, no but trauel?
Oon preiynge, and oon cursynge; whos vois schal the Lord here?
What profitith the waischyng of hym, that is waischun for a deed bodi, and touchith eft a deed bodi?
So a man that fastith in hise synnes, and eft doynge the same synnes, what profitith he in mekynge hym silf? who schal here his preyer?
He that kepith the word, multiplieth preier.
Heelful sacrifice is to take heede to the comaundementis, and to departe fro al wickidnesse.
And to offre the plesyng of sacrifice for vnriytfulnesses, and bisechyng for synnes, is to go awey fro vnriytfulnesse.
He that offrith purest flour of wheete, schal yelde grace; and he that doith merci, offrith a sacrifice.
It is wel plesaunt to the Lord, to go awei fro wickidnesse; and preier is to go awei fro vnriytfulnesse.
Thou schalt not appere voide bifore the siyt of God;
for whi alle these thingis ben doon for the heestis of God.
The offryng of a iust man makith fat the auter, and is odour of swetnesse in the siyt of the hiyeste.
The sacrifice of a iust man is acceptable, and the Lord schal not foryete the mynde of hym.
With good wille yelde thou glorie to God, and make thou not lesse the firste fruytis of thin hondis.
In ech yifte make glad thi cheer, and in ful out ioiyng halewe thi tithis.
Yyue thou to the hiyeste aftir his yifte; and with good iye make thou the fyndyng of thin hondis.
For whi the Lord is a yeldere, and he schal yelde seuene fold so myche to thee.
Nyle thou offre schrewid yiftis; for he schal not resseyue tho.
And nyle thou biholde an vniust sacrifice; for the Lord is iuge, and glorie of persoone is not at hym.
The Lord schal not take a persoone ayens a pore man; and he schal here the preier of hym that is hirt.
He schal not dispise the preyeris of a fadirles child, nether a widewe, if sche schedith out speche of weilyng.
Whether the teeris of a widew goen not doun to the cheke, and the criyng of hir on hym that ledith forth tho teeris?
For whi tho stien fro the cheke `til to heuene, and the Lord herere schal not delite in tho.
He that worschipith God in delityng, schal be resseyued; and his preyer schal neiye `til to the clowdis.
The preier of hym that mekith hym silf schal perse clowdis, and til it neiyeth, he schal not be coumfortid, and he schal not go awey, til the hiyeste biholde.
And the Lord schal not be fer, but he schal iuge iust men, and schal make doom; and the strongeste schal not haue pacience in tho, that he troble the bak of hem.
And he schal yelde veniaunce to folkis, til he take awei the fulnesse of proude men, and troble togidere the ceptris of wickid men;
til he yelde to men aftir her dedis, and aftir the werkis of Adam, and aftir the presumpcioun of hym;
til he deme the dome of his puple, and schal delite iust men in his merci.
The merci of God is fair in the tyme of tribulacioun, as clowdis of reyn in the tyme of drynesse.
God of alle thingis, haue thou merci on vs; and biholde thou vs, and schewe thou to vs the liyt of thi merciful doyngis.
And sende thi drede on hethene men, that souyten not thee, that thei knowe that no God is, no but thou; that thei telle out thi grete dedis.
Reise thin hond on hethene men aliens, that thei se thi power.
For as thou were halewid in vs in the siyt of hem, so in oure siyt thou schalt be magnefyed in hem;
that thei knowe thee, as and we han knowe, that noon othere is God, outakun thee, Lord.
Make thou newe signes, and chaunge thou merueilis;
glorifie the hond, and the riyt arm.
Reise thou stronge veniaunce, and schede out ire;
take awei the aduersarie, and turmente the enemye.
Haaste thou the tyme, and haue thou mynde on the ende, that thei telle out thi merueils.
And he that is sauyd, be deuourid in the ire of flawme; and thei that treten worst thi puple, fynde perdicioun.
Al to-breke thou the heed of princis, and of enemyes, seiynge, Noon othere is, outakun vs.
Gadere thou togidere alle the lynagis of Jacob, and knowe thei that no God is, no but thou, that thei telle out thi grete dedis; and thou schalt enherite hem, as at the bigynnyng.
Haue thou merci on thi puple, on which thi name is clepid in to help; and on Israel, whom thou madist euene to thi firste gendrid sone.
Haue thou merci on Jerusalem, the citee of thin halewyng, on the citee of thi reste.
Fille thou Syon with thi vertues, that moun not be teld out, and fille thi puple with thi glorie.
Yyue thou witnessyng, that at the bigynnyng thei weren thi creaturis; and reise thou preieris, whiche the formere profetis spaken in thi name.
Lord, yyue thou meede to hem that abiden thee, that thi prophetis be foundun trewe; and here thou the preier of thi seruauntis.
Aftir the blessyng of Aaron yyue thou to thi puple, and dresse thou vs in to the weie of riytfulnesse; that alle men wite, that dwellen in erthe, that thou art God, the biholdere of worldis.
The wombe schal ete alle mete, and o mete is betere than another mete.
Chekis touchen mete almest, and an vnwise herte resseyueth false wordis.
A schrewid herte schal yyue heuynesse, and a wijs man schal ayenstonde it.
A womman schal take ech knaue child, and a douytir is betere than a sone.
The fairnesse of a womman makith glad the face of hir hosebonde, and sche schal brynge desir ouer al the coueitise of man.
If ther is a tunge of heelyng, ther is also of swagyng, and of merci; the hosebonde of hir is not aftir the sones of men.
He that hath in possessioun a good womman, bigynneth possessioun; sche is an help lijk hym, and a piler as reste.
Where an hegge is not, the possessioun schal be rauyschid awei; and where a womman is not, a nedi man weilith.
To whom bileueth he that hath no nest, and bowith doun where euer it is derk, as a theef girt, skippynge out fro citee in to citee?
Ech frend schal seie, And Y haue couplid frenschip; but that is a frend, a frend bi name aloone. Whether sorewe is not til to deth?
Forsothe a felowe of table and a frend schulen be turned to enemyte.
A! the worste presumpcioun, wherof art thou maad to hile drie malice, and the gilefulnesse therof?
A felowe of table schal be myrie with a frend in delityngis, and in the dai of tribulacioun he schal be aduersarie.
A felowe of table schal haue sorewe with a frend, for cause of the wombe; and he schal take scheeld ayens an enemye.
Foryete thou not thi frend in thi soule, and be thou not vnmyndeful of hym in thi werkis.
Nyle thou take councel with the fadir of thi wijf; and hide thou councel fro hem that han enuye to thee.
Ech councelour schewith councel, but ther is a councelour to hym silf.
Kepe thi soule fro an yuel counselour; firste wite thou, what is his nede, and what he schal thenke in his soule;
lest perauenture he sende a stake in to the erthe, and seie to thee,
Thi weie is good, and he stonde ayenward, to se what schal bifalle to thee.

With an vnreligiouse man trete thou of holynesse, and with an vniust man of riytfulnesse, and with a womman of these thingis whiche sche hatith. With a ferdful man trete thou of batel, with a marchaunt, of cariyng ouer of marchaundies to chepyng; with a biere, of sillyng, with an enuyouse man, of graces to be don;
with an vnpitouse man, of pytee, with an vnonest man, of oneste, with a werk man of the feeld, of ech werk;
with a werk man hirid bi the yeer, of the endyng of the yeer, with a slowe seruaunt, of myche worchyng. Yyue thou not tent to these men in al councel,
but be thou bisi with an hooli man, whom euere thou knowist kepynge Goddis drede,
whos soule is aftir thi soule. Who euer doutith in derknessis, schal not haue sorewe with thee.
And stablische thou the herte of good councel with thee; for whi another thing is not more than it to thee.
The soule of an hooli man tellith out treuthis sum tyme; more than seuene biholderis sittynge an hiy for to biholde.
And in alle these thingis biseche thou the hiyeste, that he dresse thi weie in treuthe.
Bifore alle werkis a sothefast word go bifore thee; and a stidfast councel go bifore ech dede.
A wickid word schal chaunge the herte, of which herte foure partis comen forth; good and yuel, lijf and deth; and a bisi tunge is lord of tho.
A wijs man hath tauyt many men, and he is swete to his soule.
He that spekith `bi soffym, is hateful; he schal be defraudid in ech thing.
For whi grace is not youun of the Lord to hym, for he is defraudid of al wisdom.
A wijs man is wijs to his soule, and the fruytis of his wit ben worthi to be preisid.
A wijs man techith his puple, and the fruytis of his wit ben feithful.
A wijs man schal be fillid with blessyngis, and thei that seen hym schulen preise hym.
The lijf of a man is in the noumbre of daies; but the daies of Israel ben vnnoumbrable.
A wijs man in the puple schal enherite onour, and his name schal be lyuynge with outen ende.
Sone, asaie thi soule in thi lijf; and if it is wickid, yyue thou not power to it;
for whi not alle thingis speden to alle men, and not ech kynde plesith ech soule.
Nyle thou be gredi in ech etyng, and schede thou not out thee on ech mete.
For in many metis schal be sikenesse, and gredynesse schal neiye `til to colrye.
Many men dieden for glotenye; but he that is abstinent, schal encreesse lijf.
Onoure thou a leche, for nede; for whi the hiyeste hath maad hym.
For whi al medicyn is of God; and he schal take of the kyng a yifte.
The kunnyng of a leche schal enhaunse his heed; and he schal be preisid in the siyt of grete men.
The hiyeste hath maad of the erthe medicyn; and a prudent man schal not wlate it.
Whether bittir watir was not maad swete of a tre?
The vertu of tho thingis cam bi experience to the knowing of men; and the hiyeste yaf kunnyng to men, for to be onourid in his merueils.
A man heelynge in these thingis schal aswage sorewe, and an oynement makere schal make pymentis of swetnesse, and schal make anoyntyngis of heelthe; and hise werkis schulen not be endid.
For whi the pees of God is on the face of erthe.
Mi sone, dispise not thi silf in thi sikenesse; but preie thou the Lord, and he schal heele thee.
Turne thou awei fro synne, and dresse thin hondis, and clense thin herte fro al synne.
Yyue thou swetnesse, and the mynde of cleene flour of wheete, and make thou fat offryng; and yyue thou place to a leche.
For the Lord made hym, and departe he not fro thee; for hise werkis ben nedeful to thee.
For whi tyme is, whanne thou schalt falle in to the hondis of hem.
Forsothe thei schulen biseche the Lord, that he dresse the werk of hem, and helthe for her lyuyng.
He that trespassith in the siyt of hym, that made hym, schal falle in to the hondis of the leche.
Sone, brynge thou forth teeris on a deed man, and thou as suffrynge hard thingis bigynne to wepe; and bi doom hile thou the bodi of hym, and dispise thou not his biriyng.
But for bacbityng bere thou bittirli the morenyng of hym o dai; and be thou coumfortid for sorewe.
And make thou morenyng aftir his merit o dai, ether tweyne, for bacbityng.
For whi deth hastith of sorewe, and hilith vertu; and the sorewe of herte bowith the heed.
Sorewe dwellith in ledyng awei; and the catel of a nedi man is aftir his herte.
Yyue thou not thin herte in sorewe, but put it awei fro thee; and haue thou mynde on the laste thingis, and nyle thou foryete.
For whi no turning is, and thou schalt no thing profite to this deed man; and thou schalt harme worste thi silf.
Be thou myndeful of mi dom; for also thin schal be thus, to me yistirdai, and to thee to dai.
In the reste of a deed man make thou hys mynde to haue reste; and coumforte thou hym in the goyng out of his spirit.
Write thou wisdom in the tyme of voidenesse; and he that is made lesse in dede, schal perseyue wisdom; for he schal be fillid of wisdom.
He that holdith the plow, and he that hath glorie in a gohode, dryueth oxis with a pricke, and he lyueth in the werkis of tho; and his tellyng is in the sones of bolis.
He schal yyue his herte to turne forewis; and his wakyng schal be aboute the fatnesse of kien.

So ech carpenter, and principal werk man, that passith the niyt as the dai; that graueth ymagis grauun, and the bisynesse of hym dyuersith the peynture; he schal yyue his herte to the licnesse of peynture, and bi his wakyng he perfourmeth the werk.
So a smyth sittynge bisidis the anefelt, and biholdynge the werk of yrun, the heete of fier brenneth hise fleischis; and he stryueth in the heete of the furneis.
The vois of a hamer makith newe his eere; and his iye is ayens the licnesse of a vessel.
He schal yyue his herte in to the perfourmyng of werkis; and bi his wakyng he schal ourne vnperfeccioun.
So a potter sittynge at his werk, turnynge a wheel with hise feet, which is put euere in bisynesse for his werk; and al his worchyng is vnnoumbrable.
In his arm he schal fourme clei; and bifore hise feet he schal bowe his vertu.
He schal yyue his herte to ende perfitli sum thing; and bi his wakyng he schal clense the furneis.
Alle these men hopiden in her hondis; and ech man is wijs in his craft.
A citee is not bildid with outen alle these men.
And thei schulen not dwelle, nether go; and thei schulen not skippe ouer in to the chirche.
Thei schulen not sitte on the seete of a iuge; and thei schulen not vndirstonde the testament of doom, nether thei schulen make opyn techyng and doom; and thei schulen not be foundun in parablis.
But thei schulen conferme the creature of the world, and her preyer is in the worching of craft; and thei yyuen her soule, and thei axen togidere in the lawe of the hiyeste.
A wijs man schal seke out the wisdom of alle elde men; and he schal yyue tent in profetis.
He schal kepe the tellyng of named men; and he schal entre togidere in to the hard sentensis of parablis.
He schal seke out the pryuy thingis of prouerbis; and he schal be conuersaunt in the hid thingis of parablis.
He schal mynystre in the myddis of grete men; and he schal appere in the siyt of the cheef iuge.
He schal passe in to the lond of alien folkis; for he schal asaie goodis, and yuels in alle thingis.
He schal yyue his herte to wake eerli to the Lord that made hym; and he schal biseche in the siyt of the hiyeste.
He schal opene his mouth in preier; and he schal biseche for hise trespassis.
For if the grete Lord wole, he schal fille hym with the spirit of vndurstondyng.
And he schal sende the wordis of his wisdom, as reynes; and in preier he schal knouleche to the Lord.
And he schal dresse his counsel, and techyng; and schal councele in hise hid thingis.
He schal make opene the wisdom of his techyng; and he schal haue glorie in the lawe of the testament of the Lord.
Many men schulen preyse his wisdom; and it schal not be don awey til in to the world.
His mynde schal not go awei; and his name schal be souyt fro generacioun in to generacioun.
Folkis schulen telle out his wisdom; and the chirche schal telle his preisyng.
If his name dwellith, he schal leeue more than a thousynde; and if he restith, it schal profite to hym.
Yit Y schal take councel to telle out, for Y am fillid as with woodnesse;
and myn ynnere spirit seith in vois, Ye fruytis of God, here me, and make ye fruyt, as roosis plauntide on the ryuers of watris.
Haue ye odour of swetnesse, as the Liban hath.
Bringe forth flouris, as a lilee; yyue ye odour, and make ye boowis in to grace. And preise ye togidere a song; and blesse ye the Lord in hise werkis.
Yyue ye greet onour to his name, and knouleche ye to him in the vois of youre lippis, in songis of lippis, and in harpis; and thus ye schulen seie in knouleching,
Alle the werkis of the Lord ben ful goode.
Forsothe watir as an heepe of stoonys stood at his word; and as resettis of watris in the word of his mouth.
For whi pesiblenesse is maad in his comaundement; and no defaute is in the heelthe of hym.
The werkis of ech fleisch ben bifore hym; and no thing is hid fro hise iyen.
He biholdith fro the world til in to the world; and no thing is wondurful in his siyt.
It is not to seie, What is this thing, ether, What is that thing? for whi alle thingis schulen be souyt in her tyme.
The blessyng of hym schal flowe as a flood;
and as the grete flood fillide greteli the erthe, so his yre schal enherite in folkis, that souyten not hym.
As he turnede watris in to drynessis, and the erthe was dried, and hise weies weren dressid to the weies of hem; so offenciouns in his ire ben dressid to synneris.
Goode thingis weren maad at the bigynnyng to goode men; so goode thingis and yuele ben maad to worste men.
The bigynnyng of nedeful thing to the lijf of men, watir, fier, and yrun, and salt, and mylk, and breed of cleene flour of whete, and hony, and a clustre of grape, and oile, and cloth.
Alle these thingis schulen turne to hooli men in to goodis; so and to vnfeithful men and synneris in to yuels.
Spiritis ben that ben maad to veniaunce; and in her woodnesse thei confermyden her turmentis.
And in the tyme of endyng thei schulen schede out vertu; and thei schulen confounde the strong veniaunce of hym that made hem.
Fier, hail, hungur, and deth; alle these thingis ben maad to veniaunce; the teeth of beestis,
and scorpiouns, and serpentis, and a swerd punyschynge wickid men in to destriyng.
In the comaundementis of hym tho schulen ete, and tho schulen be maad redi on the erthe in nede; and in her tymes tho schulen not passe o word.
Therfor fro the bigynnyng Y was confermed; and Y counselide, and thouyte, and lefte writun.
Alle the werkis of the Lord ben goode; and ech werk schal serue in his our.
It is not to seie, This is worse than that; for whi alle thingis schulen be preued in her tyme.
And now in al the herte and mouth preise ye togidere, and blesse ye the name of the Lord.
Greet occupacioun is maad to alle men, and an heuy yok on the sones of Adam, fro the dai of the goyng out of the wombe of her modir, til in to the dai of biriyng in to the modir of alle men.
The thouytis of hem, and the dredis of herte, fyndyngis of abidyng, and the dai of endyng;
fro hym that sittith bifore on a gloriouse seete, `til to a man maad lowe in to erthe and aische;
fro hym that vsith iacynct, and berith a coroun, `til to hym that is hilid with raw lynnun cloth, woodnesse, enuye, noise, doutyng, and drede of deth, wrathfulnesse dwellynge contynueli, and strijf;
and in the tyme of restyng in the bed, the sleep of nyyt chaungith his kunnyng.
Forsothe a litil is as nouyt in reste; biholdyng is of hym in sleep as in the dai.
He is disturblid in the siyt of his herte, as he that ascapith in the dai of batel. He roos vp in the dai of his helthe, and dredynge not at ony drede, with al fleisch,
fro man `til to beeste, and seuenefold schal come on synneris.
At these thingis, deth, blood, stryuyng, and swerd, oppressyngis, hungur, and sorewe, and beetyngis;
alle these thingis ben maad on wickid men, and the greet flood was maad for hem.
For whi alle thingis that ben of the erthe, schulen turne in to the erthe; and alle watris schulen turne in to the see.
Al yifte and wickidnesse schal be don awei; and feith schal stonde in to the world.
The richessis of vniust men schulen be maad drie as a flood; and schulen sowne as a greet thundur in reyn.
An vniust man schal be glad in openynge hise hondis; so trespassouris schulen faile in the ende.
The sones of sones of wickid men schulen not multiplie braunchis; and vncleene rootis sownen on the cop of a stoon.
Grenenesse bisidis ech watir; and at the brynk of the flood it schal be drawun out bi the roote bifor al hey.
Grace as paradiss in blessyngis; and merci dwellith in to the world.
The lijf of a werk man sufficient to hym silf schal be maad swete; and thou schalt fynde tresour ther ynne.
Bildyng of a citee schal conferme a name; and a womman with out wem schal be rikenyd aboue this.
Wyn and musik maken glad the herte; and loue of wisdom gladith aboue euer either.
Pipis and sawtree maken swete melodie; and a swete tunge aboue euer either.
An yye schal desire grace and fairnesse; and greene sowyngis aboue these thingis.
A frend and felowe comynge togidere in tyme; and a womman with man aboue euer either.
Britheren in to help in the tyme of tribulacioun `coumforten myche; and merci schal delyuere more than thei.
Gold and siluer, and settyng of feet; and counsel wel plesing is aboue euer either.
Richessis and vertues enhaunsen the herte; and the drede of the Lord more than this.
Making lesse is not in the drede of the Lord; and in that drede it is not to seke help.
The drede of the Lord is as paradijs of blessyng; and `the blessyngis of God kyueriden hym aboue al glorie.
Sone, in the tyme of thi lijf be thou not nedi; for it is betere to die, than to be nedi.
A man biholdinge in to another mannus boord, his lijf is not in the thouyt of lijflode; for he susteyneth his lijf with othere mennus metis.
Forsothe a chastisid man and lernd schal kepe him silf.
Nedynesse schal be defoulid in the mouth of an vnprudent man; and fier schal brenne in his wombe.
A! deth, thi mynde is ful bittir to an vniust man, and hauynge pees in hise richessis;
to a restful man, and whose weies ben dressid in alle thingis, and yit myyti to take mete.
A! deth, thi doom is good to a nedi man, and which is maad lesse in strengthis,
and failith for age, and to whom is care of alle thingis, and vnbileueful, that leesith wisdom.
Nyle thou drede the doom of deth; haue thou mynde what thingis weren byfore thee, and what thingis schulen come on thee; this dom is of the Lord to ech man.
And tho thingis that schulen come on thee in the good plesaunce of the hiyeste; whethir ten yeer, ether an hundrid, ether a thousynde.
For whi noon accusyng of lijf is in helle.
The sones of abhomynaciouns ben the sones of synneris; and thei that dwellen bisidis the housis of wickid men.
The eritage of the sones of synneris schal perische; and the contynuaunce of schenschipe with the seed of hem.
Sones playnen of a wickid fadir; for thei ben in schenschip for hym.
Wo to you, ye wickid men, that han forsake the lawe of the hiyeste.
And if ye be borun, ye schulen be borun in cursidnesse; and if ye ben deed, youre part schal be in cursidnesse.
Alle thingis that ben of the erthe, schulen turne in to the erthe; so wickid men schulen turne fro cursyng in to perdicioun.
The morenyng of men is in the bodi of hem; but the name of wickid men schal be doon awei.
Haue thou bisynesse of a good name; for whi this schal dwelle more with thee, than a thousynde tresouris grete and preciouse.
The noumbre of daies is the terme of good lijf; but a good name schal dwelle with outen ende.
Sones, kepe ye techyng in pees; for whi wisdom hid, and tresour vnseyn, what profit is in euer either?
Betere is a man that hidith his foli, than a man that hidith his wisdom.
Netheles turne ye ayen in these thingis that comen forth of my mouth.
For it is not good to kepe alle vnreuerence, and not alle thingis plesen alle men in feith.
Be ye aschamed of fornycacioun, bifor fadir, and bifor modir; and of a leesyng, bifore a iustice, and bifore a myyti man;
and of trespas, bifor a prince, and bifore a iuge; and of wickidnesse, bifore a synagoge, and a puple; and of vnriytwisnesse,
bifore a felow, and a frend;
and of thefte, in the place where ynne thou dwellist; of the treuthe and testament of God; of sittyng at the mete in looues, and of the blemyschyng of yifte, and takyng;
of stilnesse, bifore hem that greeten; of the biholdyng of a letcherouse womman, and of the turnyng a wey of the cheer of a cosyn.
Turne thou not awey the face fro thi neiybore; and be thou war of takyng a wei a part, and not restorynge.
Biholde thou not the womman of an othere man; and enserche thou not her hand maide, nether stonde thou at hir bed.
Be thou war of frendis, of the wordis of vpbreidyng; and whanne thou hast youe, vpbreide thou not.

Double thou not a word of heryng, of the schewyng of an hid word; and thou schalt be verily with out schame, and thou schalt fynde grace in the siyt of alle men. Be thou not schent for alle these thingis; and take thou not a persoone, that thou do trespas.
Be thou war of the lawe and testament of the hiyeste, of doom to iustifie a wickid man;
of the word of felowis, and of weigoeris, and of the yyuyng of eritage of frendis;
of the euennesse of balaunce, and of weiytis, of the getyng of many thingis, and of fewe thingis;
of corrupcioun of biyng, and of marchauntis, and of myche chastising of sones; and of a worste seruaunt, to make the side to bleede.
A seelyng is good on a wickid man.
Where ben many hondis, close thou; and what euer thing thou schalt bitake, noumbre thou, and weie thou; forsothe discryue thou, ether write, ech yifte, and takyng.

Absteine thou fro the techyng of an vnwitti man, and fool, and of eldere men that ben demed of yonge men; and thou schalt be lernd in alle thingis, and thou schalt be comendable in the siyt of alle men.

An hid douyter of a fadir is wakynge and bisynesse of hym; sche schal take awei sleep; lest perauenture sche be maad auowtresse in hir yong wexynge age, and lest sche dwellynge with the hosebonde, be maad hateful;
lest ony tyme sche be defoulid in hir virginytee, and be foundun with child in the kepyng of hir fadir; leste perauenture sche dwellynge with the hosebonde, do trespasse, ether certis be maad bareyn.

Ordeyne thou kepyng on a letcherouse douyter, lest ony tyme sche make thee to come in to schenschipe to enemyes, of bacbityng in the citee, and of castyng out of the puple; and sche make thee aschamed in the multitude of puple.
Nyle thou take heed to ech man in the fairnesse; and nyle thou dwelle in the myddis of wymmen.
For whi a mouyte cometh forth of clothis, and the wickidnesse of a man cometh forth of a womman.
For whi the wickidnesse of a man is betere than a womman doynge wel, and a womman schendyng in to schenschipe.
Therfor be thou myndeful of the werkis of the Lord; and Y schal telle the werkis of the Lord, whiche Y siy, in the wordis of the Lord.
The sunne liytnynge bihelde by alle thingis; and the werk therof is ful of the glorie of the Lord.
Whether the Lord made not hooli men to telle out alle hise merueilis, whiche the Lord almyyti stidfast in his glorie schal conferme?
He schal enserche the depthe, and the herte of men; and he schal thenke in the felnesse of hem.
For the Lord knew al kunnyng, and bihelde in to the signe of the world; tellynge tho thingis that ben passid, and tho thingis that schulen come; schewynge the steppis of hid thingis.
And no thouyt passith hym, and no word hidith it silf fro hym.
He made fair the grete werkis of his wisdom, which is bifore the world, and til in to the world; nether ony thing is encreessid,
nether is decreessid, and he hath no nede to the counsel of ony.
Alle hise werkis ben ful desirable, and to biholde, as a sparcle which is.
Alle these thingis lyuen, and dwellen in to the world; and alle thingis obeien to hym in al nede.
Alle thingis ben double, oon ayens oon; and he made not ony thing to faile. He schal conferme the goodis of ech; and who schal be fillid, seynge his glorie?
The firmament of hiynesse is the fairnesse therof; the fairnesse of heuene in the siyt of glorie.
The sunne in biholdyng, tellynge in goyng out, is a woundurful vessel, the werk of hiy God.
In the tyme of myddai it brenneth the erthe; and who schal mow suffre in the siyt of his heete? Kepynge a furneis in the werkis of heete;
the sunne brennynge hillis in thre maneris, sendynge out beemys of fier, and schynynge ayen with hise beemys, blyndith iyen.
The Lord is greet, that made it; and in the wordis of hym it hastide iourney.
And the moone in alle men in his tyme is shewing of tyme, and a signe of the world.
A signe of the feeste dai is takun of the moone; the liyt which is maad litil in the ende.
The monethe is encreessynge bi the name therof, wondirfuli in to the ending.
A vessel of castels in hiy thingis, schynynge gloriousli in the firmament of heuene.
The fairnesse of heuene is the glorie of sterris; the Lord an hiy liytneth the world.
In the wordis of the hooli tho schulen stonde at the doom; and tho schulen not faile in her wakyngis.
Se thou the bouwe, and blesse thou hym that made it; it is ful fair in his schynyng.
It yede aboute heuene in the cumpas of his glorie; the hondis of hiy God openyden it.
Bi his comaundement he hastide the snow; and he hastith to sende out the leiytyngis of his dom.
Therfor tresouris weren opened, and clowdis fledden out as been.
In his greetnesse he settide clowdis; and stoonys of hail weren brokun.
Hillis schulen be moued in his siyt; and the south wynd schal blowe in his wille.
The vois of his thundur schal beete the erthe; the tempest of the north, and the gaderyng togidere of wynd.
And as a brid puttynge doun to sitte sprengith snow, and the comyng doun of that snow is as a locust drenchynge doun.
The iye schal wondre on the fairnesse of whitnesse therof; and an herte dredith on the reyn therof.
He schal schede out frost as salt on the erthe; and while the wynd blowith, it schal be maad as coppis of a brere.
The coold northun wynd blew, and cristal of watir frees togidre; it restith, on al the gedering togidere of watris, and it clothith it silf with watris, as with an haburioun.
And it schal deuoure hillis, and it schal brenne the desert; and it schal quenche grene thing as fier.
The medicyn of alle thingis is in the haasting of a cloude; a deewe, meetynge the heete comynge of brennyng, schal make it low.
The wynd was stille in the word of God; bi his thouyt he made peesible the depthe of watris; and the Lord Jhesu plauntide it.
Thei that seilen in the see, tellen out the perels therof; and we heeringe with oure eeris schulen wondre.
There ben ful cleer werkis, and wonderful, dyuerse kindis of beestis, and of alle litle beestis, and the creature of wondurful fischis.
The ende of weie is confermyd for it; and alle thingis ben maad in the word of hym.
We seien many thingis, and we faylen in wordis; forsothe he is the endyng of wordis.
To what thing schulen we be myyti, that han glorie in alle thingis? for he is al myyti aboue alle hise werkis.
The Lord is ferdful, and ful greet; and his power is wondurful.
Glorifie ye the Lord as myche as euere ye moun, yit he schal be myytiere; and his grete doynge is wondurful.
Ye blessynge the Lord, enhaunse hym as myche as ye moun; for he is more than al preisyng.
Ye enhaunsynge hym schulen be fillid with vertu; trauele ye not, for ye schulen not take perfitli.
Who siy hym, and schal telle out? and who schal magnefie hym, as he is fro the bigynnyng?
Many thingis gretter than these ben hid fro vs; for we han seyn fewe thingis of hise werkis.
Forsothe the Lord made alle thingis; and he yaf wisdom to men doynge feithfuli.
Preise we gloriouse men, and oure fadris in her generacioun.
The Lord made myche glorie bi his greet doyng, fro the world.
Grete men in vertu weren lordis in her poweris, and riche in her prudence; tellynge in profetis the dignete of profetis, and comaundynge in present puple,
and tellynge hoolieste wordis to puplis, bi the vertu of prudence.
Sekynge maneres of musik in her childhod, and tellynge songis of scripturis.
Riche men in vertu, hauynge the studie of fairnesse, makynge pees in her housis.
Alle these men gaten glorie in the generaciouns of her folk; and ben had in preysyngis in her daies.
Thei that weren borun of hem, leften a name to telle the preisyngis of hem.
And summe ben, of whiche is no mynde; thei perischiden as thei that weren not, and thei weren borun as not borun; and her sones perischiden with hem.
But also tho men of mercy ben, whose pitees failiden not;
and good eritage dwellide contynueli with the seed of hem.
And the seed of her sones sones stood in testament,
and the eritage of her sones dwellith for hem, til in to with outen ende; the seed of hem, and the glorie of hem, schal not be forsakun.
The bodies of hem ben biried in pees; and the name of hem schal lyue in to generaciouns and generaciouns.
Puplis tellen the wisdom of hem; and the chirche tellith the preysyng of hem.
Enok pleside God, and was translatid in to paradis, that he yyue wisdom to folkis.
Noe was foundun parfit and iust, and he was maad recouncelynge in the tyme of wrathfulnesse.
Therfor residue seed was left to erthe, whanne the greet flood was maad.
Testamentis of the world weren set anentis hym, lest al fleisch myyte be doon awei bi the greet flood.
Abraham was the greet fadir of the multitude of folkis; and noon was foundun lijk hym in glorie, which kepte the lawe of hiy God, and was in the testament with hym.
He made a testament to stonde in his fleisch; and he was foundun feithful in temptacioun.
Therfor God with an ooth yaf to hym glorie in his folk; God made hym to encreesse, as an heep of erthe,
and to enhaunse his seed as sterris, and to enherite hem fro the see `til to the see, and fro the flood `til to the endis of erthe.
And to Isaac God dide in the same maner, for Abraham, his fadir.
The Lord yaf to hym the blessing of alle folkis; and confermyde his testament on the heed of Jacob.
He knew hym in hise blessyngis, and yaf eritage to hym; and departide to hym a part in twelue lynagis.
And he kepte to hym men of merci, fyndynge grace in the siyt of eche man.
Moises was loued of God and of men; whose mynde is in blessyng.
He made him lijk in the glorie of seyntis, and he magnefiede hym in the drede of enemyes; and in his wordis he made peesible the wondris ayens kynde.
He glorifiede hym in the siyt of kyngis, and he `comaundide to hym bifore his puple, and schewide his glorie to hym.
In the feith and myldenesse of hym God made hym hooli; and chees him of alle men.
For he herde hym, and his vois; and ledde in hym in a cloude.
And yaf to hym an herte to comaundementis, and to the lawe of lijf, and of techyng; to teche Jacob a testament, and Israel hise domes.
He made hiy Aaron, his brother, and lijk hym of the lynage of Leuy.
He ordeynede to hym euerlastynge testament, and yaf to hym the preesthod of the folk. And he made hym blissful in glorie,
and girte hym with a girdil of riytfulnesse; and clothide hym with a stoole of glorie, and crownede hym in the ournementis of vertu.
He settide on hym sandalies, and breeches, and a clooth on the schuldur, and girte hym aboute with ful many small goldun bellis in cumpas;
to yyue soun in his goyng, to make soun herd in the temple, in to mynde to the sones of his folk.
God yaf to hym an hooli stoole, a wouun werk, with gold, and iacynct, and purpur, the werk of a wijs man, maad riche with doom and treuthe;

the werk of a crafti man, in writhun reed threed, with preciouse iemmes grauun in the byndyng of gold, and grauun bi the werk of a crafti man of stoonys, in to mynde, bi the noumbre of the lynagis of Israel.
A goldun coroun on his mytre, set forth with the signe of hoolynesse, the glorie of onour, and the werk of vertu, ourned to desijr of iyen.
Siche thingis so faire weren not bifore hym, `til to the eest.
Noon alien was clothid ther ynne, but oneli hise sones, and hise sones sones aloone, bi al tyme.
Hise sacrifices weren endid ech dai bi fyer.
Moises fillide hise hondis, and anoyntide hym with hooli oile.
It was maad to hym in to euerlastynge testament, and to his seed as the daies of heuene, to vse presthod, and to haue preisyng, and to glorifie his puple in his name.
God chees hym of ech lyuynge man, to offre sacrifice to God, encense, and good odour, in to mynde, for to plese for his puple.
And he yaf to hym power in hise comaundementis, and in the testamentis of domes, to teche Jacob witnessyngis, and in his lawe to yyue liyt to Israel.
For aliens stooden ayens hym, and men that weren with Datan and Abiron, and the congregacioun of Chore, in wrathfulnesse cumpassiden hym for enuye, in desert.
The Lord siy, and it pleside not hym; and thei weren wastid in the feersnesse of wrathfulnesse.
He made to hem wondris ayens kynde, and in the flawme of fier he wastide hem.
And he encreesside glorie to Aaron, and yaf eritage to hym; and he departide to Aaron the firste thingis of fruytis of the erthe.
He made redi his breed in the firste thingis, in to fulnesse; for whi and thei shulen ete the sacrifices of the Lord, whiche he yaf to hym, and to his seed.
But in the lond of his folk he schal not haue eritage, and no part is to hym among the folk; for whi God is the part and eritage of hym.
Fynees, the sone of Eleazarus, was the thridde in glorie, in suynge hym in the drede of God,
and to stonde in the reuerence of folk; in the goodnesse and gladnesse of his soule he pleside God of Israel.
Therfor God ordeynede to hym the testament of pees, and made hym prince of hooli men, and of his folk; that the dignete of presthod be to hym and to his seed, with outen ende.

And the testament of Dauid, the sone of Jesse, of the lynage of Juda, was eritage to hym, and to his seed; that he schulde yyue wisdom in to oure herte, to deme his folk in riytfulnesse, lest her goodis schulen be don awei; and he made the glorie of hem to be euerlastinge, in the folk of hem.
Jhesus Naue, the successour of Moises in profetis, was strong in batel, that was greet bi his name.
The gretteste in to the helthe of chosun men of God, to ouercome enemyes risynge ayens hem, that he schulde gete the erytage of Israel.
Which glorie he gat in reysynge his hondis, and in castynge scharpe arowis ayens citees.
Who bifore hym ayenstood so? for whi the Lord hym silf smoot the enemyes.
Whether the sunne was not lettid in the wrathfulnesse of hym, and o dai was maad as tweyne?
He clepide to help the hiyeste God, myyti in ouercomynge enemyes on ech side; and God, greet and hooli, herde hym, in stoonys of hail of ful greet vertu.
He made asauyt ayens the folk enemy, and in the comynge doun he loste the aduersaries;
that hethene men knowe the myyt of hym, for it is not esy to fiyte ayens the Lord; and he suede myyti men at the bak.
And in the daies of Moises he and Caleph, the sone of Jephone, diden merci; to stonde ayens the enemye, and to forbede the folk fro synnes, and to refreyne the grutchyng of malice.
And thei tweyne weren stidfast, and weren delyuered fro perel, of the noumbre of sixe hundrid thousynde `foot men, to brynge hem in to the eritage, in to the lond that flowith mylk and hony.
And the Lord yaf strengthe to thilke Caleph, and til in to elde vertu dwellide perfitli to hym; that he stiede in to the hiy place of the lond, and his seed gat eritage.
And alle the children of Israel sien, that it is good to obeie to hooli God.
And alle iugis bi her name, the herte of whiche was not corrupt, weren strong in batel, which weren not turned awei fro the Lord;
that the mynde of hem be in blessyng, and her boonys apperen fro her place;
and her name dwellith with outen ende, for the glorie of hooli men dwellith at the sones of hem.
Samuel, the profete of the Lord, that was louyd of his Lord God, made newe the empire, and anoyntide prynces in his folk.
In the lawe of the Lord he demyde the congregacioun, and he siy the Lord of Jacob, and in his feith he was preued a profete.
And he was knowun feithful in hise wordis, for he siy the Lord of liyt.
And he clepide in to help the Lord almyyti, in ouercomynge enemyes stondynge aboute on ech side, in the offrynge of a man vndefoulid.
And the Lord thundride fro heuene, and in greet soun he made his vois herd.
And he al to-brak the princes of men of Tyre, and alle the duykis of Filisteis.
And bifore the tyme of ende of his lijf, and of the world, he yaf witnessyng in the siyt of the Lord, and of Crist; he took not of ony man richessis, yhe, til to schoon; and no man accuside hym.
And after this he slepte, and he made knowun to the kyng, and he schewide to hym the ende of his lijf; and he enhaunside his vois fro the erthe in profesie, to do awei the wickidnesse of the folc.
Aftir these thingis Nathan, the profete, roos, in the daies of Dauid.
And as ynnere fatnesse departide fro the fleisch, so Dauid fro the sones of Israel.
He pleiede with liouns, as with lambren; he dide in lijk maner with beris, as with lambren of scheep.
Whether in his yongthe he killide not a giaunt, and took awei schenschip fro the folk?
In reisynge the hond in a stoon of a slynge, he castide doun the ful out ioiyng of Golias,
where he clepide to help the Lord almyyti; and he yaf in his riyt hond to do awei a stronge man in batel, and to enhaunse the horn of his folk.
So he glorifiede hym in ten thousynde, and he preiside hym in the blessyngis of the Lord, in offrynge to hym the coroun of glorie.
For he al to-brak enemyes on ech side, and drow out bi the roote Filisteis contrarie, `til in to this dai; he al to-brak the horn of hem, `til in to with outen ende.
Dauid in ech werk yaf knouleching to hooli God, and hiy in the word of glorie.
Of al his herte he heriede God, and he louyde the Lord that made hym, and yaf to hym power ayens enemyes.
And he made syngeris to stonde ayens the auter; and he made swete motetis in the soun of hem.
And he yaf fairnesse in halewyngis, and he ournede tymes `til to the endyng of lijf; that thei schulden preise the hooli name of the Lord, and make large eerli the hoolynesse of God.
Crist purgide the synnes of hym, and enhaunside his horn with outen ende; and he yaf to hym the testament of kyngis, and the seete of glorie in Israel.
Aftir hym roos a witti sone; and for hym he castide doun al the power of enemyes.
Salomon regnede in the daies of pees, to whom God made suget alle enemyes, that he schulde make an hous in the name of God, and make redi hoolynesse with outen ende, as he was lerned in his yongthe.
And he was fillid with wisdom as a flood is fillid; and his soule vnhilide the erthe.
And thou, Salomon, fillidist derk figuratif spechis in licnessis; and thi name was pupplischid to ilis afer, and thou were louyde in thi pees.
Londis wondriden in songis, and in prouerbis, and in licnessis, and interpretyngis, ether exposiciouns; and in the name of the Lord,
to whom the surname is God of Israel.
Thou gaderidist togidere gold as latoun, and thou fillidist siluer as leed.
And thou bouwidist thi thies to wymmen; thou haddist power in thi bodi.
Thou hast youe a wem in thi glorie, and madist vnhooli thi seed, to brynge in wrathfulnesse to thi children, and thi foli in othere men;
that thou schuldist make the rewme departid in to tweyne, and of Effrem to comaunde an hard comaundement.

But God schal not forsake his merci, and schal not distrie, nether do awei hise werkis, nether he schal leese fro generacioun the sones sones of his chosun kyng Dauid; and he schal not distrie the seed of hym that loueth the Lord.
Forsothe God yaf remenaunt to Jacob, and to Dauid of that generacioun.
And Salomon hadde an ende with hise fadris.
And he lefte aftir hym of his seed Roboam,
the foli of the folk, and made lesse fro prudence; which Roboam turnede awei the folk bi his councel.
And Jeroboam, the sone of Nabath, that made Israel to do synne, and yaf to Effraym weie to do synne; and ful many synnes of hem weren plenteuouse,
for thei turneden hem awei greetli fro her lond.
And the lynage of Effraym souyte al wickidnessis, til defence cam to hem; and delyuerede hem fro alle synnes.
And Elie, the profete, roos as fier; for whi his word brente as a brond.
Which brouyte yn hungur on hem, and thei suynge hym weren maad fewe for enuye; for thei myyten not suffre the comaundementis of the Lord.
Bi the word of the Lord he held togidere heuene, and castide doun fro it fier to the erthe.
So Elie was alargid in his merueils; and who may haue glorie in lijk maner with thee, which tokist awei a deed man fro hellis,
fro the eritage of deth, in the word of the Lord God?
Which castidist doun kyngis to deth, and hast broke togidere liytli the power of hem, and gloriouse men fro her bed.
Which herdist dom in Syna, and in Oreb domes of defence.
Which anoyntist kyngis to penaunce, and makist prophetis successouris aftir thee.
Which were reseyued in a whirlwynde of fier, in a chare of horsis of fier.
Which art writun in the domes of tymes, to plese the wrathfulnesse of the Lord, to recounsele the herte of the fadir to the sone, and to restore the lynagis of Jacob.
Thei ben blessid, that siyen thee, and weren maad feir in thi frenschipe;
for whi we lyuen oneli in lijf, but after deth oure name schal not be siche.
Elie, that was hilid in a whirlewynd; and his spirit was fillid in Elisee. Elisee in hise daies dredde not the prince, and no man ouercam hym bi power;
nether ony word ouercam hym, and his deed bodi profesiede.
In his lijf he dide wondris ayens kynde; and in deth he wrouyte merueilis.
In alle these thingis the puple dide not penaunce, and yeden not awei fro her synnes, til whanne thei weren cast awei fro her lond, and weren scatered in to ech lond.
And a ful fewe folk was left, and a prince in the hous of Dauid.
Summe of hem diden that, that pleside God; but othere diden many synnes.
Ezechie maad strong his citee, and brouyte watir in to the myddis therof; and diggide a rooche with irun, and bildide a pit to watir.
In hise daies Senacherib stiede, and sente Rapsaces; and he reiside his hond ayens hem, and he reiside his hond ayens Syon, and was maad proud in his power.
Thanne the hertis and hondis of hem weren moued; and thei hadden sorewe as wymmen trauelynge of child.
And thei clepiden to help the merciful Lord, and thei spredden abrood the hondis, and reisiden to heuene; and the hooli Lord God herde soone the vois of hem.
He hadde not mynde on her synnes, nether yaf hem to her enemyes; but he purgide hem in the hond of Isaie, the hooli profete.
The aungel of the Lord castide doun the castels of Assiriens, and al to-brak hem.
For whi Ezechie dide that that pleside the Lord, and yede strongli in the weie of Dauith, his fadir; which weie Isaie, the grete profete, and feithful in the siyt of God, comaundide to hym.
In the daies of hym the sunne yede ayen abak; and God encreesside lijf to the kyng.
With greet spirit Ysaie siy the laste thingis; and he coumfortide the moreneris in Sion, `in to with outen ende.
He schewide thingis to comynge, and hid thingis, bifore that tho camen.
The mynde of Josie maad in the makyng of odour, is the werk of a pyment makere.
In ech mouth his mynde schal be maad swete as hony, and as musik in the feeste of wyn.
He was dressid of God in the penaunce of folk; and he took awei the abhomynaciouns of wickidnesse.
And the herte of hym gouernede to the Lord; and in the daies of synnes he strengthide pitee.
Outakun Dauid, Ezechie and Josie, alle kyngis diden synne.
For whi the kyngis of Juda leften the lawe of myyti God, and dispisiden the drede of God.
For thei yauen her rewme to othere men, and her glorie to an alien folk.
Thei brenten the chosun citee of hoolynesse; and thei maden the weies therof forsakun in the hond of Jeremye.
For thei tretiden yuel hym, which from the wombe of the modir was halewid a profete, to turne vpsedoun, and to leese, and efte to bilde, and make newe.
Ezechiel, that siy the siyt of glorie, which the Lord schewide to hym in the chare of cherubyn.
For he made mynde of enemyes in reyn, to do wel to hem, that schewiden riytful weies.
And the boonys of twelue profetis apperen fro her place; and thei strengthiden Jacob, and ayenbouyten hem in the feith of her vertu.
Hou schulen we alarge Zorobabel? for whi and he was a signe in the riyt hond of God to Israel;
and Jhesu, the sone of Josedech? whiche in her daies bildiden an hous, and enhaunsiden the hooli temple to the Lord, maad redi in to euerlastynge glorie.
And Neemye in the mynde of myche tyme, that reiside to vs the wallis, `that weren cast doun, and made the yatis and lockis to stonde; which Neemye reiside oure housis.
No man borun in erthe was such as Enok; for whi and he was resseyued fro the erthe.
And Joseph, that was borun a man, the prince of britheren, the stidfastnesse of folk, the gouernour of britheren, the stablischyng of puple;
and his boonys weren visitid, and profesieden after deth.
Seth and Sem, these gaten glorie anentis men, and ouer ech man in the generacioun of Adam.
Symount, the sone of Onyas, was a greet preest, which in his lijf vndursettide the hous, and in hise daies strengthide the temple.
Also the hiynesse of the temple was bildide of hym, the double bildyng, and hiy wallis of the temple.
In the daies of hym the pittis of watris camen forth; and as the see tho weren fillid aboue mesure.
Which Symount helide his folk, and delyuerede it fro perdicioun.
Which was myyti to alarge the citee; which gat glorie in the conuersacioun of folk; and alargide the entryng of the hous, and of the large cumpas aboute.
As the dai sterre in the myddis of a cloude, and as a ful moone schyneth in hise daies;
and as the sunne schynynge, so he schynede in the temple of God;

as a reyn bouwe schynynge among the cloudis of glorie, and as a flour of rosis in the daies of veer, and as lilies, that ben in the passyng of watir, and as encense smellynge in the daies of somer; as fier schynynge,
and ensence brennynge in fier;
as a sad vessel of gold, ourned with ech preciouse stoon;
as an olyue tree spryngynge forth, and a cipresse tree reisynge it silf an hiy; while he took the stoole of glorie, and was clothid in the perfeccioun of vertu.
In the stiyng of the hooli auter, the clothing of hoolynesse yaf glorie.
Forsothe in takynge partis of the hoond of prestis, and he stood bisidis the auter. The coroun of britheren, as a plauntyng of cedre in the hil Liban, was aboute hym;
so thei stoden aboute hym as boowis of palm tree, and alle the sones of Aaron stoden in her glorie.
Sotheli the offryng of the Lord was in the hondis of hem, bifore al the synagoge of Israel; and he vside ful endyng on the auter, to alarge the offryng of the hiy kyng.
And he dresside his hond in moiste sacrifice; and sacrifiside in the blood of grape.
He schedde out in the foundement of the auter, the odour of God to the hiy prince.
Thanne the sones of Aaron crieden lowde; thei sowneden in trumpis betun out with hameris, and maden a grete vois herd in to mynde bifore God.
Thanne al the puple hastiden togidere, and fellen doun on the face on the erthe, for to worschipe her Lord God, and to yyue preyers to almyyti God an hiy.
And men syngynge in her voices alargiden; and a soun ful of swetnesse was maad in the greet hous.
